People know that if you want a well-made cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen unit, Hurst is the person to see. Finding a furniture-maker isn't hard, especially in the countryside where the craft is thriving. But finding one who focuses on beautifully crafted furniture with clean, simple lines is more challenging. 'There are few real cabinet-makers now. People call themselves furniture-makers,' Hurst says with a sigh. As a craftsman with high standards, he is often disappointed by modern furniture. 'I'm amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people accept.' He criticizes poorly made, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who produce low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are key to his success. Hurst is confident in his abilities. 'I have a huge natural ability,' he says seriously. 'I've always been good at making things.' If not for his self-deprecating tone at the end of our interview, I might have thought his confidence was entirely genuine. Hurst is self-taught. How did he learn his craft? 'I asked the right questions and picked it all up,' he says casually. Most of his work comes from private clients. 'I used to do some commercial work for companies, but it was soul-destroying.' Some clients return repeatedly. 'You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying.' But he admits that client relationships aren't always smooth. 'The most frustrating clients are those who don't know what they want and then decide when it's too late... my favorite clients are the demanding ones.' While Hurst has reasons to be proud, he also praises others when deserved. With a touch of modesty, he says, 'There are people far better than me. I can admire other people. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham' (a top furniture design college). However, he criticizes craftsmen who 'try to be artists and take a year to make one piece.' He also dislikes degree shows where students display their work while 'trying to make fashion statements. That can be pretentious. A piece of furniture should be something people can really use.' Hurst is confident and sometimes abrupt, but neither he nor his work is pretentious. His final comment shows a practical approach to his craft and a hint of humility that contrasts with his earlier confidence. 'After all, I am only making furniture,' he says as I leave.'

Text: 'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. It seems clear that sleep has an important role. However, what that role is remains uncertain. Scientists do not fully agree on why we spend so much time sleeping. There are three main theories. The most common theory suggests that sleep is mainly for physical health. It says we sleep to keep our bodies healthy. While we sleep, our bodies repair damage from the day and restore full efficiency. Another theory focuses on the learning benefits of sleep. It suggests that sleep helps us process information we learn during the day, and without sleep, learning would not happen. A third theory is about energy. It says we need sleep to recharge our energy for the next day.'

**Eccentrics**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and who doesn't follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Most people have their own quirks, like entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the press about everything. Eccentricity is about showing our uniqueness. Inside us, there is a constant struggle between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains on the same track, one called individualism and the other conformity. For most people, the desire to fit in is stronger. We want to be accepted and loved, more than we want to stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often gather together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting. We all feel a tension between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. We might say things like, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me," to show our individuality.

At any time, we can choose to be more individualistic. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said that when you follow your gut and don't give up, you might confuse people. But this self-assertion isn't eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to get noticed, that's not eccentricity. However, if they keep doing these things until they can't go back to 'normal' behavior, then they might be considered eccentric.

The key to eccentricity is being natural. Eccentrics don't try to be odd; they just are. They don't care about public opinion and are barely aware of it. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses, who are all very aware of society. Eccentrics simply do what they do because of who they are, without worrying about the world around them.

**Natural Books**

We asked four leading naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've had the privilege of meeting some of the pioneers in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe and developed a compelling philosophy from her experiences. As a young journalist, her work helped me understand the field. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man," despite its old-fashioned title even in 1976, is her most important book to me. It focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the themes she dedicated her life to, like sustainable development. I've read hundreds of books since, but none match its impact.

**B Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can vividly imagine the sounds and smells of a herring gull colony. This book brilliantly explains animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony transforms from chaos to an efficient social structure. You can identify partners, boundaries, and families. Niko Tinbergen was a distinguished behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with wildlife artist Eric Ennion was inspirational. Ennion's spontaneous painting style, developed from years of observing birds, captures the essence of their behavior with minimal lines and color. This is the work of a true field naturalist.

**C Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell has had the greatest influence on my life. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This extraordinary book solidified my devotion to the natural world. I first read it while researching animal vocalizations in Madagascar. Despite setbacks, reading this book made my world brighter. It weaves animals, people, joy, and beauty together, showing a world worth saving. Many criticize our species for harming others, but Gerald's view of the world as a family, with all its members intertwined, is a concept we need to understand.

**D Bruce Pearson**

I discovered "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after its 1966 publication. I was immediately drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. These images captured my attention and encouraged me to start sketching birds to aid identification. The book offered more than just beautiful paintings; it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This broad range of information and exciting images led me to appreciate birds and nature more generally. It showed me that an emotional and creative response to nature is as valid as a scientific one. As art was my stronger subject, this book opened a new path for me.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five leading British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are crucial for publishers; they are the first thing we look at in newspapers. The Book Marketing Council found that more people buy books because of reviews than any other reason, like ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually less upset by bad reviews. They believe that any attention, whether good or bad, can boost sales as readers want to form their own opinions. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own views of a book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but their needs differ. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviewing is more diverse and less elitist than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are still often overlooked. Publishers shouldn't complain too much, as reviews are a cost-effective way to promote books. A lively review by a trusted critic can increase sales, especially if there are multiple reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are vital for literary publishing. We rely on them because our books are not by famous authors and we rarely advertise. Positive reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as unbiased. Good reviews can boost sales significantly, but they need to be combined with other factors like word-of-mouth, support from bookstores, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
The link between publishing and reviewing in Britain is unclear. In the U.S., a review in the New York Times can greatly impact a book's success. In Britain, bookshops often ignore reviews. It can take years of good reviews for a writer to gain readers, while poorly reviewed books can still sell well. The process is unpredictable, though non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer's knowledge than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for positive reviews, but do they sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, yet it didn't sell because people felt they didn't need to read the book after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's the unexpected choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that can drive sales.

Text: The craft of making weathervanes dates back to ancient Egyptian times. Today, Graham Smith keeps this tradition alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs tailored to his customers' needs. 'This way, I can make a personalized item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want something special that reflects the man's work or hobbies.' This is quite different from the traditional cockerel design. Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick, made as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends admired it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I realized there are endless possibilities for designs,' he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, switched rolesâ€”she worked as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for their children and build the business. That was five years ago, and he has no regrets. 'My previous job lacked creativity, but this is exciting and artistic,' he says. 'I love the design aspect.' Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He works with great detail, always getting customer approval before cutting. He also keeps traditional designs in stock, as they are popular. 'People like handcrafted items,' Graham says. 'They enjoy having something unique.' Graham has no plans to expand, wanting to keep the business a rural craft. 'I have found my niche. People appreciate individuality, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something lifelike,' he says. 'For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand weather changes by showing wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want unique touches for their homes. This has helped crafts like mine.' Graham is busy supplying flat-packed weathervanes worldwide, with interest from American and Danish buyers. 'Pricing depends on the design's complexity,' he explains. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.'

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans earned him record-breaking amounts of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success story.

The start of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and aspiring director. His year began poorly when a film project called *Life and Limb*, which he had been working on for months, suddenly fell apart. This was a big disappointment and a source of worry for him. It had been two years since he last earned any money, and the film was his only hope to keep his bank manager at bay.

In a situation like this, a sensible person might have looked for a job. Evans could have returned to being a television executive or started a TV project he had put on hold. Instead, he made a bold decision that many, including himself, might have thought was crazy. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.

Although this decision was impulsive, the idea for the story had been with him for a while. It was inspired by a farrier he met on Dartmoor, who told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were known as "horse whisperers," and this story captured Evans' imagination.

Initially, Evans thought of writing a screenplay about it, as he was a filmmaker. However, after the disappointment with *Life and Limb*, he decided to write it as a book. So, in the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing people, but I felt very alone, and it seemed like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By August, he had returned home and written the first half of the book. The bank manager was becoming increasingly demanding, and Evans needed to know if it was worth continuing. He gathered the courage to show the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and estimated Evans might get $30,000 as an advance. Evans needed more than that to pay off some of his overdraft and support his family. He had already spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and needed at least two more months to finish it. $30,000 was a difficult amount to consider. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, the first 200 pages of the novel, along with the synopsis, were sent to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just sense something is happening.'"

What happened next became publishing history. Within a week, after intense bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking advances for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were in shock. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent there, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."

The studios agreed to this amount, and they each made their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four major filmmakers called, one after the other, to bid for the rights to his unfinished novel.

Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on the verandah of his home. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been such a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is tough, and I don't want to become an employee of people I like and who have paid me so much. I'd hate to write a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"

He planned to be involved, but from a distance. The success of his novel also brought new offers to back *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

Text: 'Young Masters Age is a challenge for Bobby Fischer as he tries to make a comeback. Chess is now more than ever a game for young people. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer has returned to chess to play against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer's win in the first game was impressive, simple yet deep. However, as the following games have shown, this older, bearded player is not the same as he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer's own influence helped make chess more professional. Now, the focus is more on winning than on the scientific and artistic aspects of the game. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intellect and wisdom. The game has always been intense: a chess clock ensures each player makes the required moves in the given time, or they lose the game. Now, games are longer, and many are played without breaks. This increased pressure benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the world's top ten players, eight are under 30. It's not just how the game is played that has changed. Much of modern chess happens off the board, not just in the psychological battles Fischer is known for. Every professional must prepare seriously before a match, especially because computer databases have changed chess. A small computer can hold a million chess games and provide instant access to an opponent's past games. In a recent match, both players had large teams working nonstop to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are now analyzed in great detail. Being better prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, there are more top-level players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for modest prize money worldwide. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours. For a chess master, this is a constant struggle. A moment of lost focus can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the tension. The end of the game often involves a frantic 'time scramble'. In these moments, each player has only seconds to make several moves or lose the game. With minds racing and hands moving quickly, the masters make their moves and press their clocks with coordination that any athlete would admire. These moments are not for deep thinkers. The game becomes a basic struggle where nerves, determination, and a strong will to win decide the winner. At the top level, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress and tiredness. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. The chess master must be ready to compete the next day. Most chess tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day, and there is a year-round tournament circuit. World championship matches are even tougher. The 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about two stone (10kg) in weight. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his departure from chess after 1972 seem even more puzzling. But in some ways, it was a fitting end to his story. It made Bobby Fischer a legend. If he has returned for the money, he will do well. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Fischer has come back truly believing he can prove he is still the best, the final result could be very disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune: New British Talent**

**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, is a playwright with three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a screenplay. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over Â£30 million, but it could be as low as Â£30." Interestingly, before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he admits. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because of the logistical issues. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very stimulating."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has progressed significantly since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a straight actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comic team Funny Business, but his collaboration with Steve Coogan has been the most rewarding. "He saw my show, and as I was a huge fan of his, he probably saw me mimicking him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became known when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The critical response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great showcase for me," he says. "I can now choose what I do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was destined for success. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But I decided to pursue it because I had a knack and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for recognition but is thoughtful about fame. "At 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize it's not about that. It's about getting respect for good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company's idea of good sales is different from mine," he says. "They're talking about a smash hit, but I have no idea. If two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to break into the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix." It happened at the perfect time. "There were times I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won more prizes and awards than many twice his age. He is well-known on the poetry circuit, where he has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became disenchanted with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving critical acclaim, moving into novels is brave. "There's a framework with poetry and less chance to do something wrong," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for mistakes. My main goal is not to produce work without caring about quality."

**A.** Isabel, the main character in this quirky novel, is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romances. She thinks she looks good in jeans but avoids wearing them to not attract the wrong crowd. Isabel is searching for Mr. Right but worries her knobbly knees might be a problem. Despite her concerns, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired.'

**B.** This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of Francis With, a smart but weak child. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of dime stores, old cars, and the radio.

**C.** In this story, it's normal for a second husband to chat with his wife's first husband. So, when successful professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poet, he naturally talks to his wife's ex. The poet writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she also wants his help for her brother, who is wrongly imprisoned. However, the real interest lies in how the author cleverly resolves these issues. The plot is moved along with humor and a keen look at relationships, making it a sophisticated and witty read.

**D.** Two pairs of best friendsâ€”two women and two menâ€”meet in 1960s London and remain connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, the mysterious American businessman James Hudson, is launching a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, all written well. This book is large and detailed, allowing readers to really get to know the characters.

**E.** Written by a top American fiction writer, this funny and heartfelt story is about Ian Bedloe, who, feeling guilty for a past mistake, becomes the 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, Ian is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor, surrounded by the chaos of family life. The story explores many emotions and focuses on the touching relationship Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It's a warm book with a perfect mix of sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism: Perspectives from Four Academic Writers**

**A.** The direct impact of volunteer tourism on development is often questioned. Volunteers, especially during gap years, may help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a fee to participate. This money, if given directly to local communities, could fund more labor than the volunteer provides. Many studies question whether gap year volunteering is truly altruistic or if it's more about gaining 'cultural capital' for career benefits. However, these projects might help volunteers develop a lifelong commitment to ethical actions that support less privileged communities.

**B.** Volunteering can foster international understanding, conflict resolution skills, and global participation through civic organizations. It can also create international social networks. Ideally, both volunteers and host communities benefit, contributing to the global good. However, if volunteering is mostly accessible to people from wealthier regions, it may primarily benefit these individuals, offering them career advantages while doing little for communities without access to such opportunities. Volunteers might use these experiences as a step towards personal advancement.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as imperialistic or self-serving, focused on personal and career growth for affluent Westerners. At its best, it benefits both volunteers and host organizations, allowing for the exchange of skills and cultural experiences. Importantly, volunteering can increase awareness and commitment to addressing power imbalances, poverty, and unsustainable development.

**D.** Volunteer tourism aligns with the trend of life strategies aimed at helping others. These strategies, focused on 'making a difference,' can seem appealing in an anti-political climate. They avoid big government and business but also bypass democratic processes, reducing development to individual charity acts. While volunteer tourism can be simple charity, when marketed as sustainable development, it may degrade the development discourse. This approach can shift focus away from understanding global inequalities and poverty.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many of us use a radio to wake up in the morning, often needing an external push to get out of bed. Enter the clock radio. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

The first model's "dual alarm function" isn't what I expected. It doesn't let you snooze with a buzzer and then wake up later. Instead, it allows setting two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and another for weekends. But who lives by such a strict schedule? This model, priced similarly to the second one we tested, includes a cassette player, which is a great deal. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We all agreed the radio quality was excellent, though the size was a downsideâ€”it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges noted, "Any clock radio I buy must leave space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. Plus, I always book a wake-up call just in case."

This model was the most attractive and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," although the clock on his test model "kept getting stuck at 16.00." I was impressed by the digital display with its grey numbers on a green background. The wide snooze bar is easy to tap with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons, like pebbles, tempted me to play with them, which was a problem when I finally looked at the 50-page instruction booklet. The clock has a self-power backup, so you don't need to reset it if someone unplugs it for a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner, which we all appreciated. However, setting it up was technically challenging, though mastering it made us feel "cool" and sophisticated.

Tom Granger found the model with an extra built-in lamp "unbelievably tacky." "You have to yank the light out of its socket to make it work, which makes me question the quality of the rest of it." He had to read the instructions twice to get it working; the clock kept jumping from 12.00 to 02.00. The light was hard to position and only shone on the clock, which was already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer was like a submarine alarm, making me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market.

Aimed at young people with its bright colors and bootlace strap, this model appealed to Tom Granger and me. "I would choose this one because it stands out," he said. The traditional controls made it the only one we set up without the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a 20-minute margin for error; the manual says, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges dismissed this, calling it "terribly fiddly" and "completely useless."

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger for being "standard and compact," and for its old-fashioned dial tuning. "It's more intuitive to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed everything correctly, so you can't trust it to work." He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality due to button-tuning. I found the tuning crude, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model was effective; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Text: 'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, making their spines point outwards. The success of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have evolved to be lighter, so they have fewer spines and might try to run from attackers, using their ball-rolling ability only if necessary. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, either under bushes or in holes. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; in good conditions, some stay awake all year.'

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in sports is challenging for everyone, but women often face additional hurdles. Training and competitions demand sacrifices, leaving little time for a normal life. Despite these challenges, many women are overcoming obstacles and setting new records. Here, we talk to a few remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land smoothly, but it can be frightening. Sometimes you feel unwell or it's windy and visibility is poor, but you just push through. It's hard to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You sacrifice a lot of your social life and friendships. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equallyâ€”it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was surprising since I'd never cycled before! I'm well-paid as a professional, and cycling offers many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I've succeeded because of my looks, not my skills. So, I focus on cycling rather than earning money. I train at least four hours daily on the bike, plus stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the time commitmentâ€”it would be impossible otherwise."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

"Rowing is tough for girls to start because few girls' schools offer it. Most don't begin until they're 19 or 20, making it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches often stay for only a year, so there's no continuity, and the women's squad is disorganized. But it's great fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the worldâ€”I didn't realize how big it was! Britain felt too small and safe. I was headstrong and disliked anyone controlling me. Now I'm more tactful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the most painful experience I've had. I walked 50 miles and 21 hours daily with three hours of sleep, in high temperatures, and with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, as my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Men often think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as riskier."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

"Some men have big egos when drivingâ€”you see it on motorways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has disadvantages. At corners, men think 'I've got to beat her,' so I've had many collisions! You need to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's tough to earn money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have raced since the twenties and were seen as eccentric. It's great that more women are racing each year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is striving for perfectionâ€”always trying for a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

"I get up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There's a lot of nervous anticipation before races, and you really push yourself during themâ€”you don't feel good if you don't. I've often asked myself why I do it. The answers are: a) I'm happier when I'm fit, b) I'm naturally lazy and would be a slob if I didn't push myself, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the press, 90% of the article focuses on the men's event, with only 10% mentioning the women's event. The prize money isn't as good either. But we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

Title: The Day I Met Picasso

Richard Cork shares his experience of meeting the famous artist Picasso when he was an 18-year-old student. While traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van, Richard ran out of money and took a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, he saw Picasso having lunch at a restaurant in the harbor. Picasso was known to be a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him there with his wife, Jacqueline, and friends.

Encouraged by a friend, Richard approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso not only signed his sketchbook but also added a lively drawing. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, though they needed an American woman at the table to translate between English and French.

After showing his friend the autograph, Richard was encouraged to return and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard began sketching. Picasso noticed and playfully made faces, making it difficult for Richard to draw. Eventually, Picasso settled down, allowing Richard to capture his likeness. Richard observed Picasso's youthful appearance and intense eyes, despite his age.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and then decided to draw Richard in return. In a few quick strokes, Picasso created a whimsical version of Richard's face, moving one eye onto his nose and capturing his smile with a single line.

Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature. Despite this, Richard felt incredibly fortunate to have met Picasso and received his attention, which meant a lot to him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Encourage You to Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here, we explore the strategies shops use to encourage spending.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. To create this impression, they often place fruits, vegetables, or even house plants at the store entrance. An in-store bakery might spread the smell of fresh bread throughout the store. The store's color scheme, like using green, can also enhance this fresh image. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't fit this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales, especially in supermarkets. With computerized stock control, supermarkets know which areas attract the most shoppers. High-profit items or fast-selling products are placed in these spots. The saying "eye-level is buy-level" means that shelves at eye height are prime locations for products. Special offers in "dump bins" attract bargain hunters. Another tactic is "complementation," where related items, like salad dressings and salads, are placed together.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets often place essential items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to pass by other tempting, higher-profit products. Similarly, chain stores might place popular items far from the entrance, relying on customer loyalty to lead shoppers through the store, exposing them to other products.

**D. Less Sells More**

Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from the "pile them high, sell them cheap" model. Instead, they display fewer items, creating a boutique feel and making the products seem exclusive. This success is due to both good store design and appealing clothing.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers often focus on the total bill rather than individual prices. Supermarkets use this by offering a mix of low and high mark-up items. Not everything in a supermarket is cheap. Some items, known as "loss leaders," are sold at a loss to attract customers. More often, low prices come from buying in bulk or meeting sales targets, which earn discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**

In chain stores, shoppers buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. Pricing a blouse at Â£14.99 instead of Â£15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as staff must process the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for natural lighting to show clothes' true colors. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh produce look more appealing.

**H. Walk This Way**

Some chain stores use different carpeting to guide shoppers. One pattern marks the main routes, while another defines sales areas. This "Yellow Brick Road" approach isn't always successful, as some shoppers stick to the main paths. Marks and Spencer, for example, use wood or marble for routes, encouraging shoppers to step onto the more inviting carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

As you enter a supermarket, large photos of delicious foods greet you, especially tempting if you're hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" with screens that advertise products as you shop. Sensors trigger ads relevant to the section you're in, like ready-made meals near the cook-chill cabinets. These trolleys target impulse shoppers and reportedly boost sales by about 30%.

Text: 'Mountaineer Chris Bonnington, known for climbing Everest in 1985, has also created new routes in Britain and the Alps and written books like Quest for Adventure. Robin Knox-Johnston started his sea career in the Merchant Navy and was the first to sail solo around the world in 1968-9. He also set a transatlantic record, sailing from New York to the Lizard in 10 days. The two teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, which they wrote about in their book Sea, Ice and Rock. In 1979, while working on Quest for Adventure, I contacted Robin for an interview. He invited me to sail with him, where I could teach him climbing, and he could teach me sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed, anchored, and then went ashore to climb. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat. The climb was tough, but Robin was steady and calm. At one point, we reached a big drop. Robin had never climbed before, so I showed him how. He then asked to descend using his boat technique, which he did safely. This trip to Skye was the start of our friendship. Robin later suggested a joint trip to Greenland, combining our skills. Robin impressed me as a leader. He consulted everyone before making decisions, which was unusual for a skipper. Although I found sailing boring, Robin enjoyed it. He liked fixing things on the boat, while I felt a bit useless. The yacht was crowded with six people in a space meant for four. In Greenland, when it was my turn to lead, I found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety. Climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, was challenging. Robin wasn't a natural climber, but he was determined. Our first attempt took 24 hours, and we were exhausted. Robin trusted me completely, even when we had to turn back. Despite his worries about the boat, he supported trying the climb again. The only tension between us was on the way home. I missed a watch shift because Robin didn't wake me, thinking he could manage alone. I felt insecure, but Robin reassured me. By the end of the Greenland trip, I realized Robin was a kind and sensitive person beneath his tough exterior.'

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been with us since ancient times, in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, the late 20th century risks losing this heritage.

**Prehistoric Wild Apples (8,000 BC)**

Humans have eaten apples since prehistoric times. In Neolithic Britain, people spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and wrinkled, known in Ancient Britain as 'windings'. They were very different from today's apples.

**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**

The French learned fruit-growing from the Romans, which they developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The dessert apple, Decio, was introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, most Roman apple varieties didn't suit the British climate, so Norman varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and develop new apples, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**

Several apple types became popular in Britain in the 13th century. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking partner was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296 to the late 17th century, giving us the word 'costermonger' for a street fruit and vegetable seller. However, apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern-style orchard in Kent.

**Settler Treasure (1750)**

By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia; Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers brought them to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', was a famous apple planter. Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was seen as a medicine man by the Indians, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious devotion inspired many folktales.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**

Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from a dead tree's roots. The apple was named 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, 'Delicious, delicious!'. In 1895, it was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples worldwide.

**Granny Smith (1850)**

Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and worked as a midwife in New South Wales. Known as 'Granny Smith', she managed the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree, she said, 'It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish', referring to both the fruit and her convict origins.

**Uniformity (1950)**

Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, rather than taste. This uniformity is reducing the variety and gene pool of apples. While UK gardeners have preserved many old varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from 100 years ago. Consumers are now demanding more variety. We can't rely on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity. We must value and protect natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide leads in adventure travel, offering trips for those seeking more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unique destinations with creative itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people, allowing for a more personal experience. This setup helps you connect with local cultures and people, making your journey more enriching.

**Varied Travel Modes**

We use different types of transport, often within the same trip. This includes chartered coaches, local buses, trains, expedition vehicles, minibuses, boats, canoes, rafts, camels, light planes, and walking. Each trip adapts to the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are adventurous and adaptable, mainly from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Most are aged 25-55, with half being couples and the rest solo travelers.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique, so we categorize our adventures into 8 themes, highlighting key activities and interests. These include cultural experiences, wildlife encounters, and more. Unique places, local customs, and personal involvement enhance your holiday.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Many trips focus on culture, exploring local traditions and historic sites. Destinations include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Turkey, India, China, Peru, and more. Short walks to off-the-beaten-path sites are common.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our safaris visit top game parks, offering close encounters with wildlife. In Africa, you might track gorillas in Zaire or canoe on the Zambezi River. Accommodations range from camping to hotels and lodges.

**Ethnic Encounters**

Meet ethnic or tribal peoples like the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to promote understanding and minimize cultural impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Some trips include easy hikes through scenic areas, with accommodations in hotels or village huts. Luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a daypack.

**Major Treks**

For strong hikers, we offer treks in mountain ranges like the Himalayas and Andes. These involve high altitudes and may include camping or staying in local homes.

**Wilderness Experience**

Explore remote wilderness areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These adventures offer a chance to experience untouched natural beauty.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

Relaxing holidays on local boats, such as felucca sailboats in Egypt or gulets in Turkey. We explore islands in places like Greece and Indonesia.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River trips range from short paddles to multi-day adventures on rivers like the Urubamba in Peru. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly.

Richard Nerurkar, a top British 10,000-metre runner, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a mountain track leads from a quiet road from Nairobi to Mount Kenya, the country's highest peak. This area, Nanyuki, has been my base for winter altitude training in Kenya's Central Highlands for three years. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until my fourth trip. During this visit, I competed in my first race in Kenya's thin air and stayed at the national team training camp, where top runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I couldn't miss. Training at high altitude increases red blood cells, improving oxygen capacity, which has benefited many Kenyan runners. My first African race, held in Nairobi, was the continent's first international cross-country race. It was a humbling experience, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, all but three of whom were Kenyan. Despite this, I felt I hadn't run poorly. I don't think Kenyan success is solely due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple approach to the sport, with an effortless running style, simple diet, and relaxed conversation. They also love competing. The least discussed aspect of their success is their training. My stay at the Kenyan team training camp provided answers. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mt Kenya, surrounded by playing fields and tropical vegetation. It's basic, with few comforts. Athletes live with regular students, six to a room in dormitories. Their days include three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The day starts at six, with a briefing from coaches. "Run easy, you have a hard job today," we were told. They cover about 40 kilometres daily, just short of a marathon. Sundays are easier, with only one 20-kilometre run. Life outside running is simple. A splash of water and brushing teeth are enough before breakfast, which includes tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar: ugali, stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to bathe in streams from Mt Kenya's glaciers. By the time I left, I appreciated Kenyan success even more. It's not just genetics, upbringing, or altitude. I considered another explanation: the simple lifestyle, tough workouts, and passion for success might be the real reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Advertising is struggling, and it's not just because of the recession. The decline started in 1989, before the recession hit hard. The main issue is that advertising hasn't kept up with economic changes. Advertisers focus on mass markets and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become more fragmented. Even big brand campaigns should aim at smaller audiences, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Consider your shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items, but only a few are advertised brands. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For consumer durables, maybe a dozen a year. Cars? If you have a new one, it's likely from your employer. If not, you buy one every three years. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even with all the services and products you purchase, you likely don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

Compare this to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more than Â£50,000 a year on advertising. The average person buys 400 of these, not all because of advertising. That's about 4%. So, the saying that half of advertising is wasted is an understatement; it might be 96%.

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. For most, it's about 1 in 16 (6%), meaning 94% are wasted. You might think you're not influenced by advertising, but most people aren't. Waste is part of media advertising. Not everyone will buy the brands they see advertised. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so waste is unavoidable.

However, advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the right audience, as advertisers can't predict who will respond. Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to communicate with the masses. But all waste is unfortunate. With better targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more potential buyers, but they can never know exactly who will respond. Even the best direct mail campaigns don't get a 100% response.

This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. With media, that's impossible. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media. This applies to all types of ads, from personal notices to soft drink commercials. An advertiser gaining one million new customers (2% of the adult population) is successful. For soap powder, the top brands would be thrilled with a million extra customers. Any campaign that wins over 2% of the population is very successful, but that's still a small minority. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more precisely than ever before.

Text: 'Solar Survivor Charles Clover explores Britain's most eco-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has some surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. Another is Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', created by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle sewage into garden compost, and heat their home with waste heat from appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and blends with the town's nineteenth-century buildings. It was approved by planners even though it's in a conservation area. The solar-powered doorbell is silent, and the house is super-insulated with triple-glazed windows, making it very quiet inside. Once inside, you must remove your shoes, and there's a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Vale opens ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is well-sealed. Even the cats have an air-locked door. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been committed to the environment since the 1970s, when they wrote a book on green architecture. They designed a building that emits no carbon dioxide and decided to do without mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to protect drinking water, which is filtered before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they avoid dishwashers to prevent using strong detergents. Most features are designed to be environmentally friendly. 'We wanted to show that you can design a house that is less harmful to the environment without living in darkness,' says Robert. The house's only medieval feature is its aesthetic: the hall, with a hearth and staircase, spans the building's full height. The Vales pay no water bills, and last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. Soon, solar panels will be installed, reducing electricity use further. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will generate a surplus. Eventually, there will be enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove, rarely used. Is it warm in winter? One February night, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The room temperature was 18C, comfortable because there are no draughts or heat loss. Perceived temperature depends on these factors. An Edwardian lady was comfortable at 12.5C due to her clothing's insulation. Robert suggests people in old houses should live as they did in the past, though this idea may not catch on. The house is low-tech, with little to go wrong. Most materials came from a builder's merchant and were installed by local craftsmen, making it cheap to build, similar in cost to low-cost housing. Commercial builders are resisting this idea.'

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, considered himself a rational man, even a scientist. However, in 1920, when he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden, he believed they were scientific proof that these tiny creatures existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, recognizing fairies as supernatural wonders. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick challenges a basic idea of photography, that the camera cannot lie. But it can, and always could. Today, we are familiar with computer software that lets us change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a true age of innocence. From the moment cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

Text: 'Blacksmiths Throughout history, iron has fascinated people, and those who work with it, blacksmiths, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they were the only ones who could make weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created the intricate ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were always crafted by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s in Britain, these skills were nearly lost because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used elegant wrought-iron designs. In the past 10 years, there has been a revival due to increased interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Still, much of the work seems outdated: makers of gates and balconies often describe their products as 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. Trendy design stores are filled with rusty candlesticks with decorative bits. Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmith's craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says: 'We might be entering a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently.' Power tools have freed blacksmiths from hard labor, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld metal more easily. 'In short,' says Dawson, 'these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves.' About 250 pieces are on display, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at Â£90 and go into the thousands. Most of the money will go to the makers, 'but a percentage of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork,' says Dawson. His own works include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. 'My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space,' he says. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's very soft when hot, but becomes rigid and immovable when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans' steel door-knockers and handles seem inspired by the castles in horror films. One design looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. 'I love that steel is cold and hard,' she says. 'And it feels like it will last forever.' No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. Iron is likely to be used decoratively for the next thousand years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.'

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**

I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was really angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't explain how, in just one afternoon, I went from being a lifelong smoker to not smoking at all. It even surprises me. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I hadn't planned to quit, and I didn't really want to. I was annoyed by the constant pressure from anti-smoking groupsâ€”and I still am. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. "I won't be trying to stop myself; it wouldn't be fair," I said. "Since I'm here to write, not to quit, it wouldn't be right to expect your method to work on me." I thought I was being reasonable. After all, I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me pleasure. I noticed the counselor looked at me knowingly. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so filled with smoke that we had to open the windows. I found it interesting that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want toâ€”and neither did the others.

I guess the stop-smoking messages made sense. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of stopping started to seem appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel powerful. It was a personal feeling, just for me. Could I also conquer the world? In many ways, it was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, like hunger, faded after a minute or two, and I only felt it for four or five days. The one thing I thought would be hardestâ€”working without cigarettesâ€”wasn't a problem at all. I believed I couldn't meet deadlines without nicotine and would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, spending weekend mornings at home was the hardest partâ€”and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; having a cigarette was an activity itself. Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each new experience as a non-smoker needs to be facedâ€”eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, a theater break. These are key moments when I used to smoke.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize, yet she is not well-known in her own country. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's first biography, has noticed that many people in Britain are unaware of Hodgkin's achievements. If Hodgkin had won a Nobel Prize in literature, she would likely be a household name. However, despite her remarkable life and contributions to science, she remains relatively obscure.

Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary individual. Her life mirrored significant changes in the 20th century, such as the progress of women's education and the globalisation of science. When Ferry began her research, she looked into scientific biographies and found that even Linus Pauling, a prominent chemist and Nobel laureate, was not well-represented in British bookstores. This reflects a broader issue where scientific biographies are often undervalued compared to those of artists or writers.

Some scientists themselves have doubted the appeal of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once remarked that scientists' lives often make dull reading. This perception contributes to the lack of interest from publishers and booksellers. The idea that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists or politicians is unfounded. In fact, some scientists avoid media attention to maintain their credibility, which can create a false impression of science and deter young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, this is changing. Scientists like Richard Dawkins and Steve Jones are appearing in public in new ways, helping to humanize the field. The publishing world is also evolving, with more engaging scientific biographies emerging. Richard Feynman's memoir, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", was a turning point, showing that scientists can have fascinating personal lives.

Dorothy Hodgkin's scientific achievements include solving the structures of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964. She balanced her scientific work with a family life, having three children and a husband who was often away. Her ability to integrate her personal and professional life is inspiring.

While her personal life may not directly relate to her scientific work, it is part of what makes her story compelling. Understanding the passion that drives scientists like Hodgkin is challenging for biographers, as many readers lack the scientific background to fully grasp complex ideas. However, learning about scientific achievements is no more difficult than understanding literature or learning a new languageâ€”it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that many educated people remain unaware of the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin. Recognizing her name and achievements should be as common as knowing distinguished literary or artistic figures.

Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills

Margaret Wilkins is known for her special ability to find water using a forked hazel rod. This skill, often called a 'sixth sense', makes her popular among farmers whose wells have dried up. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business, using modern equipment like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. Their success rate in finding water is over 90%.

Dowsing is the skill of finding water, minerals, or lost objects underground. There are many theories about how it works, from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ones. A common theory is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Dowsers, like Margaret, might have a heightened ability to sense these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' or even smell water.

In recent drought years, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She also helps owners of remote cottages or barns, now used as holiday homes, where installing water pipes is too costly. Golf-course developers also seek her help for clubhouse facilities.

Margaret aims to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. She avoids drilling where farm waste might contaminate the water. The water she finds flows through cracks in solid rock, ensuring a clean supply. However, in Cornwall, where she works, there is a risk of finding iron-rich water. Electricity is needed to power the pump, so the well should be near existing power lines.

To find water on large properties like golf courses, Margaret starts with a map and a pendulum. She moves the pendulum over the map, and it swings over areas with water. Then, she walks the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a peculiar sensation and uses the stick to pinpoint the exact spot to drill. Holding the stick's forks, she applies tension, and the stick rises when water is below. It's crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates, as even a small mistake can miss the water. Her husband also checks the area, and they only drill when they agree on the spot.

Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition in England. Anthropologists and writers are intrigued by this mysterious intuition. Margaret calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment', which helps explain her accuracy in finding water. Without this 'sixth sense', her family couldn't sustain their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone for a day? Maybe you think it would be exciting to try something different. We arranged this for four people. Hereâ€™s what happened.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, a 30-year-old waitress at a busy London restaurant.

I had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. The atmosphere was amazing, but I wasn't sure I could handle it. Being a mother is busy, but this was something else! I had just 15 minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but I dropped the drinks, and they crashed to the floor. I was embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said everyone makes mistakes at first.

By opening time at 11:30 am, there was already a queue outside, and I felt nervous. Remembering orders wasn't a problem because everything was automated. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn't get used to the loud music. I had to keep saying 'Pardon?' to customers, which was embarrassing. By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was exhausted and wanted to soak my feet. I couldn't believe it when a waitress said it had been a 'quiet' day!

I never realized how tiring waitressing could be. I thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be outgoing and handle lots of customers. I'm quite shy, and I don't think I could manage on a busy Saturday night. I wasn't impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me! I was glad to return to my children. It seems easier after waitressing!

**Cindy's Story**

I was nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was excited too. I was told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. I was wrong! After Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong again! Amanda left a note reminding me to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and screamed loudly! I thought they'd get tired, but they didn't. I thought I had stamina, but they beat me! I managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but then they kept asking for water to come downstairs and watch TV. It was exhausting negotiating with them all evening.

I never realized how tiring it could be to look after two small children. You don't get a moment for yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Even so, I enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher.

On the farm, I get up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a luxury! I worried about what to wear. I couldn't show up in overalls and boots! At assembly, I faced about 400 pupils and hoped I blended in. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, which was different from my school days when we recited tables together.

Then I helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was exhausted and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (bliss!) and then a French lesson. The children wanted to practice on me, which showed my rusty French. Finally, we had Physical Education. I was drained, but the children had endless energy.

The hardest part was speaking in front of the class. Even for two minutes, it's daunting. Teachers may get more holidays, but I think I'll stick to farming!

**Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find Rosemary had been up for three hours! Her 280-acre farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which are sold in shops and restaurants.

I spent the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk, making ice cream, and labeling cartons. It was hard not to taste the goodies! At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. I picked up a ewe that had fallen over. If left for more than 12 hours, they could die, so they need daily checks. What a nightmare in winter!

After feeding the calves, I started milking. It took two-and-a-half hours, and Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! I found it lonely and missed the children. Animals don't talk back! The worst part is not being able to get away from work. The cows need milking twice a day, so it's hard to plan time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is different. The income is irregular, and I'd hate to depend on the weather.

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player by the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new works. When you meet him, he appears younger than his age, with a fresh and open manner, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV feature highlighted his work and development, filmed in both the UK and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother found a teacher for him, the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who quickly recognized his talent. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a dedicated teacher, who was passionate about the trumpet and connected with players worldwide. Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a primitive instrument with imperfections, and it's about understanding and working with them. From the start, he had the ability to find the right balance and develop his unique sound. Unlike John Wallace, a great British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances. His parents supported his ambition, and at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening.
