They would have weekly lunches to choose what to review from the material Tom selected, with guests to keep things sociable. It felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and Mark was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market, just as unlikely as a millionaire wanting to help him personally. Mark lacked self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to his review, he felt awkward. Tom's idea for a team of critics never worked out. It was a good idea, but they didn't meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. The public preferred reviewers to focus on one subject, so Mark chose film. Without Tom's initial push, they wouldn't have the current setup, where Mark writes a detailed weekly piece, usually on one film. This way of working suits him. He wouldn't have liked the typical film critic's job of reviewing every film, which would quickly bore him. He would dread watching films he didn't enjoy. The space he has allows him to expand his arguments or, in a dull week, create something interesting. But what is his role in the public eye? He thinks people choose films based on stars, publicity, or directors. Loyalty to a genre or its opposite also plays a role. It's rare for someone who dislikes westerns to watch one after reading a review, or for a romance fan to skip a love story because of a review. So, if a film review isn't a consumer guide, what is it? Mark doesn't feel responsible for being 'right' about a movie. He doesn't think there should be a set number of 'great' or 'bad' films each year. His job is to present an argument. He's not a judge, nor does he want to be.

Text: Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager with a passion for endurance sports WANTED: Training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. Opportunity to train with a potential Olympic champion. Must be very enthusiastic about distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (enjoys winter training in cold rivers), and distance cycling (loves 100km rides). Ability to do all three without resting is essential. The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently, it has attracted large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, and then running 10km without stopping. It's exciting for spectators, but why do triathletes push their bodies so hard? And why would a talented 17-year-old with excellent academic results give up everything for this challenging sport? Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenge, and higher goals that most athletes use. "You swim 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. After the 40km cycle ride, you have to run 10km, which feels long when you're exhausted. But it's great fun, and all worth it in the end," she says. Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior competing. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my teammates as I went around." Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second-fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place. "I was following this man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried throughout the run." But she didn't give up and is determined never to. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would be over, but I'm afraid that if I let myself stop once, I would be tempted to do it again." Such determination draws admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I've just been testing her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She had given it everything, but while most people step off when they can't go any further, she just kept on." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard at it." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will cover the Â£1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a Â£2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with Â£1,000 off") so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another cost. Her intense training sessions have made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, what sort of times they are achieving." Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events. She has attempted the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. Funny, that.

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her love for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It's a world full of passion and excitement. But remember, only collect items you truly love.

Since ancient times, people have felt the urge to collect. Early humans collected pebbles for their beauty and wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their shapes and colors.

I've been a collector all my life, gathering everything from tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I went to a school in a remote, windy part of England. My parents would take me to a local museum filled with fascinating objects collected by others.

Many people share my interest in collecting. The reasons vary, but some find it gives them a sense of control. For me, it's simply enjoyable. Historical collectors like the Duc de Berry in France had 'rooms of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be wealthy to collect; I've collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination.

I once convinced a fellow tulip collector to give me a bulb I wanted. Sadly, it was later stolen. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire, which was very upsetting.

I'm fascinated by how collections change hands. A silver spoon once owned by a king or poet gains value because of its history. As items become popular among collectors, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable investments, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I regret throwing mine away along with the toys.)

**My Line of Work: Four People Talk About Their Jobs**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions. This involves planning, designing, and promoting them. I research the exhibition topic and consult with experts to define the main themes and goals. I decide which objects and pictures to display and ensure the public understands the exhibition's concept. This includes planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also coordinate with engineers and electricians to ensure safety. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform the public.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I prepare new maps and documents for learning the routes needed to pass the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are figuring out the best routes, considering one-way streets and turns. I step in when there's a disagreement, like whether a right turn is possible at a junction. As they near the test, I challenge them by closing off their chosen routes, making them find alternatives. This helps them think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and work from home. My job includes answering phone enquiries, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. I often work with schools and study centers, and I run courses for coastal managers. I take them out to sea to help them understand marine life better, which often changes their perspectives. I love my job because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means constantly needing more funds, which limits what I can achieve.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain stock of about 300 books. We uphold high standards of information and content. We receive many letters about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there's too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

Text: 'No Title We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who bought the house, the Malseeds, have expanded it, but they've done it very discreetly. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. We had gone away together the summer before to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't successful because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school, as Dekko Deacon sounds quite good. He and Strafe went to school together, which is why we call Strafe by his surname, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. Quite a coincidence, we always think. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling her welcome again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive, as she's rarely not waiting in the large, low-ceilinged hall that always smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she instructed the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' She referred to the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when few people visit Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of details like that; her husband handles redecoration and repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled broadly, his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel like more than just hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I felt the others thinking our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; all was well. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led us to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not as long as usual because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full: from where we sat by the window, we could see some strolling on the lawns, others taking the cliff path to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years, this pattern had developed. Since we first came here, we'd all fallen in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.'

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live at the chalet. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing the guests' breakfast. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest has finished breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go skiing herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m.' Sometimes they are confused and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was about six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of wiry hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could see his factory, and sometimes he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving them a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how Marie's father made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand,' Seymour replied. She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' He was pleased that she was interested in every detail. 'They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet,' she said. 'Well, you should visit one if you're writing about leather. I can arrange that for you. They're primitive places. Technology has improved things, but it's not much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere, with 6,000-year-old relics discovered in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. It's an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for days. That's typical: glovemen love the trade. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have,' she replied. 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She had made him laugh. She was an eager learner, full of spirit. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. The intelligent enthusiasm that filled the house when Marie came home from school, full of what she'd learned. How she remembered everything, neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to take you through the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it a tough job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often has to travel at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small issue - she dislikes flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down,' she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so cramped with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. Her tasks include organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. A chance meeting with a pop group's manager led to an offer to work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy, especially since golf is his passion. However, there were downsides. Caddies earn a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings. Average earnings are between Â£25,000 and Â£35,000, much of which goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, who made him a statistical data administrator. He compiles and analyzes statistics from cards brought in by caddies, which are used by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try dishes at top restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend Â£120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking talent led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, then a creative director at an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still cooks at home and tries to keep fit by cycling a few miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but mostly wrote verse. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing out the morning's notes - all with one finger on an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that's the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were large piles of soft sawdust, like golden mountains, reaching down to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, Michael and his friends climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof, landing on the sawdust and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, encouraging them to follow. Laughing, he watched them hesitate, but one by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes until one of them said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went back up and jumped off again, determined, until only Michael was left. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the roof, nervous and unsure why it seemed so much higher this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists, trying to count to ten and jump. When that didn't work, he tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. The others started laughing, tired of waiting, and it was getting late. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they began to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, staring at the ground, feeling unhappy. He was alone for nearly an hour as the sun set, a big orange ball over the lake. His clothes were wet with sweat from nerves. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was silent; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to be home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled severity, but Michael, gloomy and miserable, barely heard her. He was still thinking about the grinning faces and their laughter.

Text: 'Careers Advice Are you unhappy in your job but unsure how to change? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change jobs are turning to careers advisers. You'll need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help create a summary of your skills and suggest possible careers and retraining options. I decided to try Career Analysts, a large career advice organization. Taking the test felt like being back in school exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions quickly. It was important to remember that it wasn't about passing or failing. The psychometrics involved tasks like finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the tests, I had a long discussion with an adviser who gave me a report with observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of the conclusions, though I was surprised to learn I did poorly in scientific and technical tests. It's probably good I didn't become a nurse. However, I was reassured to hear I made the right choice in journalism. Rethinking your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, after five years as a marketing manager at an insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to review my career and skills,' says Donna. Some results were surprising. 'I didn't know I had a talent for design. But I had to consider the cost of retraining against my financial needs,' she says. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my existing skills and move to a job better suited to me than insurance. I'm now a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to friends who are also happy with the service.' Some people feel they wouldn't have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make big decisions. 'After six years at a bank, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course this year. The advice was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.' However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I was unsure about my career path. I hoped a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt a friend could have given similar advice.'

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you'll notice bright modern paintings and a stylish blue couch where patients sit during their check-ups. Jerome explains, "Half of the people only visit the dentist when they're in pain, not for regular check-ups. They're scared." To change this, he has created a welcoming environment. "That's why I don't wear a white coat. People often link it with pain. I believe dental treatment should be relaxing, interesting, and even enjoyable."

This approach is surprising for many who associate dental visits with pain or clinical settings. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they'll forget past negative experiences." One of his new techniques is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first in Britain to use them, and they're very popular. During the initial check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view of their mouth." Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit.

Another important aspect is the pleasant smell in the office, more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today, it smells of orange. Jerome says, "I want people to realize with all their senses that this isn't a typical dentist's visit. Smell is crucial. The usual dental smell can make people anxious." I found the scent in the office very pleasant.

Although known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. Relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of treatment is the top priority. For instance, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels unusual at first, but it's not painful if people are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to research dental techniques. "I learned that making it easier for the patient makes it easier for the dentist," he says. He sees his patient-focused approach as the beginning of a shift towards less formality in British dentistry.

Just then, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business. During Easter, people in the UK spend over Â£230 million on chocolate, with eight percent of all chocolate sales happening at this time. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. Large-scale chocolate production began in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago.

The cacao tree is an evergreen, tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a 17th-century misspelling.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish preferred it with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.

Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, giving us milk chocolate.

At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to add some French charm. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, launched as Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising linking it to the healthy qualities of English countryside milk, challenging the more luxurious French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars each week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. The latest trend is the 'extended line,' where chocolate bars become ice creams, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to those tired of regular snacks.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices at the end of the 1980s. Many small-scale farmers were forced out of business. Perhaps you could think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83, Peter Cooke has mastered his art. He still wants to try new things like paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the past ten years. As he shows me around his apartment, he worries about being boring, but his charm and the beauty of his work make him an enthusiast, not a bore.

Cooke points to shell-covered ornaments above a fireplace, saying he wouldn't mind if they don't sell because he loves them. He never intended to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to hold an exhibition. The result was a successful show in London, where 70% of the pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday, with prices reaching around Â£2,000 for some ornaments. Cooke is open about the prices, claiming no one else creates work like his. The gallery owner told him that once he stops, his pieces will become even more sought after.

Cooke wishes he had started earlier, as he feels physically limited now, but he still produces remarkable work. His creations are far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He has a "miniature mind," leading to intricate boxes, shaded pictures, and realistic flower baskets made from shells. Cooke has developed his own methods, using materials he finds, like cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases and a special glue from a sail-maker. He washes the shells with washing-up liquid. Although he claims his work "just does itself," the detail, color gradations, and symmetry show careful attention.

His search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him beyond Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. Cooke only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming beaches. He argues that people walking on the beach destroy shells faster than he can collect them, and the sea breaks up the rest. He insists he never collects shells with living creatures or dives for them. His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work, which often surpasses the natural beauty of the shells themselves.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer isn't traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's likely studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I had been trying to convince myself that all the negative things I had read about models were untrue, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided a trip to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be rushing. She could be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira wasn't wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained, and apart from looking very young, her mother was a normal mum - clearly proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. It was her older sister who decided she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When the call came to tell her she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work.

Kira now finds that one of the hardest things she has to do is manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers have gotten used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This kind of remark must be hard for Kira to deal with, since there can't be many people as successful as her who are less self-important. But she says, "They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident - not in a bad way, but I'm able to stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, though, her social life is obviously affected. The Select agency can call at any time and tell her she is needed for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out together, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a fabulous career ahead of her. And not many people can say that before they even sit their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the outstanding beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Search for Gold

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat in search of gold. Terence, an explorer, and his son Chris, a mineral expert, believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "We are finding high levels of gold; we just need to dig a few more meters to reach where it is concentrated."

Their gold search began when Terence read about gold worth millions in the "Dolgellau gold belt," near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding gold bits in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running out of money. They need to find a backer to invest Â£50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "It looks doubtful, but we have some people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but I hope millions don't come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed recently. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of finding hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. When she isn't teaching, she dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration. Inside, space is so tight that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move, and must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant trip.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment there to study the effects of a program that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research into "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees. The only time Rachel was scared was during a dive with Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere beneath all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more stress. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign schedules, currencies, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the following year. And the next. All I needed was one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere in Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, the rhythm rocking you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your belongings in a backpack makes you have a very basic approach to travel, and encourages incredible wastefulness, like burning socks that have become too unpleasant, and getting rid of books when finished. On the other hand, this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail, where common sense and reasoning can be thrown out along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to achieve this carefree attitude is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I initially thought this type of train ticket was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting, as there was always just one more country over the border, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in planning our own schedule, we left out everything except the most immediately available sights. This was a chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I took great pride in the fact that, in many places, all I bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and to have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city you arrive in never actually existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you see it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't allow you to discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best opportunity to recognize this ... though in our case it didn't happen immediately.

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your baggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and have to wear unsuitable clothes. Airlines rarely say how many bags they lose, but regular travelers will eventually face this issue. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can guarantee that your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes. 

Here's how the system works. Airlines require you to check in early to give enough time for your baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Normally, the system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause problems. These issues are more common at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to Latin America.

To avoid losing your baggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or want a cheaper flight, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

Text: 'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, partly shading the shallow water. The main colors are soft greens, mud browns, and the many yellows of sunlight, as gentle as the sounds of water in the breeze. The bird moves quickly through the scene, like a flash of light and motion that is so striking you almost feel it. It disappears in a split second, but the image stays in your mind, its impact much larger than its size. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He can't quite explain what draws him to this little bird, which is part of many legends. In Greek myth, the kingfisher is a moon goddess who turned into a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some scientific truth to this. Despite the many blues in their feathers, kingfishers have no blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light and reflects blue. This is why a kingfisher can appear to change from bright blue to rich green with a slight change in light angle. It's no wonder some wildlife photographers are so enthusiastic about them. The colors, combined with the fact that kingfishers, though shy, can be watched from a hideout, create a lifelong passion. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. But it took him four years to get his first good picture. Meanwhile, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream rich with kingfishers. School limited his time with the birds, so he skipped classes, becoming what he calls an 'academic failure'. But his interest in the kingfisher, the only member of its family to breed in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and gradually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the ultimate kingfisher film. 'No speech, just beautiful images that say it all,' he says. 'I'm drawn to the simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings...' His sentence trails off as he thinks of the bird's colors that still excite him after so many years. His photographs convey some of his feelings, but as Charlie knows, there's much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.'

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. ANNE MANSON**

Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she asked to observe Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna and ended up filling in for an absent assistant. This led to more opportunities, including assisting Abbado on several projects. Manson, originally from the US, now works with a London-based opera company focused on modern works and is gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**

Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after previous unsuccessful attempts. The win provided many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, Constantine is concerned about being permanently labeled as a "competition winner." He hopes to be known for his work with orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which continues to invite him back.

**C. WASFI KANI**

Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods of opera productions. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties, supporting herself with a job in London's financial district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional. Lessons with Sian Edwards were pivotal for her, as Edwards was similar in stature, which made a big difference. Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, including managing singers' personalities.

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**

Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly fascinating. He started as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's "Agrippina" from the piano at a festival, which was easier than he anticipated. Vignoles feels his broad musical experience benefits him in conducting. He is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys most.

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**

Wayne Marshall, now 32, was noticed by conductor Simon Rattle in 1986, which led to his first conducting job in London. Despite challenges, like dealing with musicians who were not fully engaged, he remained firm and clear in his direction. Marshall has never formally studied conducting but relies on his determination and clear vision. He believes in expressing his needs confidently to get the best results.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. Thereâ€™s a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay longer. Our only complaint is that the park lacks atmosphere, and the scenery could be better. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and focused on security.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didnâ€™t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is perfect, and the staff are friendly. Thereâ€™s something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, especially the trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think youâ€™ll get wet, but you donâ€™t. Toy Land is great for younger children. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small for it, which was a relief for us! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isnâ€™t too boring. Itâ€™s very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldnâ€™t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at one oâ€™clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides arenâ€™t too scary. Iâ€™m usually afraid, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didnâ€™t try the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europeâ€™s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the most terrifying ride according to Ben, although Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older kids went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldnâ€™t have dared to tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**

**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly turnover of over Â£200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Having worked with computers before marriage, her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. Christine was careful with finances, always informing the bank manager if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, with local clients often collecting their work.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She says, "I enjoy being independent." After studying art at university, she wanted to work in a museum, but living in the countryside offered no such opportunities. So, she started her own business, creating 50 different greeting cards sold to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is the constant distraction of household chores. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, the benefits outweigh the drawbacks.

**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started eight years ago when the business was growing, and her turnover increased from Â£24,000 to Â£80,000 in two years. She once managed six full-time curtain-makers but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was difficult as jobs are scarce in the area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and employs women who work from their homes. Delia adapts by cutting prices when needed and exploring new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and her love of the country. She enjoys flexible working hours, though 80% of her income comes from international deals, requiring calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to separate work from home life. Tessa publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated, having gained all her professional experience in London.

**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly turnover of Â£250,000, employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is now made, employing a baker, assistant, and professional cake-icer. Meg no longer bakes herself, focusing on the business side. Her biggest challenge has been managing finances, as they started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is unique because not only are the sons composers and award-winning musicians, but their father also makes musical instruments. John and Hetty Watkins, schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, to match his growing talent. The cost of buying one was too high, so John decided to make one himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul, now 28, used this cello until recently. John has since retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American violinist Jaime Laredo was a highlight for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano and then moved to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Although his parents wanted him to play the violin, he preferred the cello. Huw, now 22, chose the piano and composition, finding inspiration in Paul's success.

Paul's cello, made by his father, helped him win the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. He now plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. John admits the new cello has a special quality that his own creation might develop over time.

Paul will soon perform Elgar's Cello Concerto on television with his Rugeri cello. However, he won't be able to watch it because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will need to be both diplomatic and energetic to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules in the coming weeks.

Text: 'Caring for the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'You also need to be good with people because you're always dealing with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building firms.' Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience got him the job, even though he didn't have formal training. 'It's helpful that I still farm with my parents and can relate to farmers and understand their problems. Also, they can't fool me about anything!' he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job - putting up fences, planting trees, building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to pick and press flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. Recently, I wondered where I would find all those flowers, birds' nests, and grasshoppers now. It's clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault - they were just following government advice.' Gareth says that, when he started, farmers and conservationists were against each other. Both sides wanted things done their way. Now they are talking and understanding each other's views. 'We're at a crossroads and just need a small step to bring them together,' says Gareth. Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with public access to the Trust's land, tree planting and maintenance, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My role is to ensure jobs are completed with minimal fuss and cost. What I enjoy most is seeing projects finished, although about half my time is spent on reports, signing bills, and so on.' Gareth is passionate about his job and, despite never being off duty, he enjoys every minute of it, especially talking to the public. Most of them, anyway. 'It's the attitude of some people I dislike,' he admits. 'They just come into the area, demand everything, then leave as if it's their right. Having to be nice to those people is annoying!' But as Gareth says, it's all about common sense. So if you have plenty of that and like the idea of an outdoor job, you might consider applying to become a warden like Gareth - but don't expect a job to be available on the Lleyn Peninsula for many years!'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her typical day includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. When asked if she gets strange looks, she said, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra's life is now all about being at her best for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to reach peak fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they are expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. A home crowd will have expectations and give more support. People will expect us to start with a strong game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." England is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra notes that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win, but the Championships are different. There's only one chance, and you have to be ready."

In her 15 years at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But after the final whistle, we become different people. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. My role is to support and encourage the team."

Kendra's netball career has always been carefully planned. She decided some time ago that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should parents handle a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always easy to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not even notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. While most schools can support children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, which are relatively new. They offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, students spend one-third to half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, though students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living full-time at the school, which allows them to grow up with peers who share similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from Â£12,000 to Â£17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop 'rounded and well-balanced individuals.'

Separating musically gifted children from an early age can be stressful. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a strong sense of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help and advice when needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some question the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide about specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, like a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with top teachers and orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden provides many of her painting subjects, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly, spreading seeds throughout the garden. The garden has a harmonious mix of colors, shapes, and structures, thanks to the previous owners who were passionate gardeners. They left behind plants that Susan liked, and she also inherited their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and Danny understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint certain plants.

Susan focuses on detailed studies of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants in the garden, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one." This process can take years to complete a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they decay fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up when placed in water.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers at first, thinking they looked artificial. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Now, her garden includes plants from distant places like China and the Himalayas, which thrive as if they were native.

Susan has a relaxed approach to gardening, similar to an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to spend time gardening. She hired an extra gardener but believes that to stay connected with her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'IsÃ¨re, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not 'live in'. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing the guests' breakfast. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest has finished breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves to, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go skiing herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning intensely. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are disoriented and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.'

Text: 'Changing Lives with a Stranger'

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear was difficult because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, and here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't usually stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there.'

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. 'I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa.'

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. 'I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job.'

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it was satisfying.'

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and I felt differentâ€”people looked up to you. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult.'

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this, but it inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier.'

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journeys**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it is always enchanting. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**B. Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many rail journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**C. Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved.
