Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding preparations.

**D. Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliableâ€”we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still on their way. When it appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriagesâ€”some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**E. Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite impressions of trains when they are young, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming took place on an old, disused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my passion for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I went back last year, it was as if time had stood still. Everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Who should I send it to?' The first thing to know is that you should research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Turning words into something sellable requires knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever you write, you need to understand the markets you're targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant. Use your local library and visit bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will guide you on what kinds of writing publishers are accepting. This knowledge needs updating as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new talent; as writers, we must give them what they want. At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. If you want to write short love stories, find out which magazines publish them and get recent copies. Familiarize yourself with the stories they buy and note who the readers are. These readers expect different things, and the editor focuses on their needs. Writers often send me stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But it's unlikely the work is ready for publishing, so I give an honest opinion with a positive outlook. Most new writers are too eager to send their work out, often before they're ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work for the first time, start on more work while waiting for a reply; write ten more stories, even twenty. Each one will be better, and you'll start to see yourself as a writer, with growing fluency and confidence. Don't throw any awayâ€”improve them instead. I advise not showing your work to others, especially early on. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. See if there's a creative writing course nearby. If not, join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The usual airy, clean feeling of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came to a girl standing near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn't mind talking to her myself. The man asked, 'Are you travelling to Philadelphia by any chance?' 'Well, I'm going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 'Ma'am,' I heard him ask an old lady, 'are you travelling to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he didn't respond, just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't; I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then moved to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She lowered her book. She was around thirty-five, older than me. A school-teacher type. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favour?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my wrist as if checking a watch. (I don't own a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like pets on leashes. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, then went for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia, unsure what to do.' The woman clucked sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. 'I told her to stay put. Stay right there, I said, and I would find someone here to bring her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a weak excuse, in my opinion. Also, it was more bad luck than one family should have. I glanced at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have been logical, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel the contents! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.'

Text: 'Gary and Me John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and mine was running a restaurant. When I found out about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in bad condition, but it was perfect for my plans. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother working in a factory and feeling upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I managed the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been great for our children, Gary and Joe. They're both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life. Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he worked for pocket money. He started with odd jobs and by ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He would wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very academic, but he excelled in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He could produce over a hundred meals, and I knew he'd go into catering because he had talent. So when he needed work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. Who knows what will happen to his cooking if the music takes off. My advice to Gary is: if you chase two hares, you catch neither, so focus on the one you can catch. He understood when I told him: 'Gary, if you want to succeed, do it by 30. If not, it's too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He'd prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping others. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cookery series has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work hard for it because no one gives you anything. He's seen his opportunity and grabbed it with both hands. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they take in even ten percent of what you've told them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.'

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But for someone like Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts to rely on. She had to stay in a hostel and search for a place on her own. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She never questioned why she was going; it was just assumed by everyone at her school that she would leave. Who would want to stay in a small, remote town? That's all she had heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates had moved to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle in. But none of them were going to Dublin. Jo was going on her own. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, which was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who seemed to have been rejected, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued climbing. "Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo realized Pauline was a punk, which surprised her. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one before. "I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called," she said. Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs. One said "Nessa," one said "Pauline," and the other said "Other." "We'll put your name on it if you stay," she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society warns that dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds discusses the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. The North Sea harbour porpoise population, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000.

You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could become a major wildlife disaster. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out at sea and are rarely seen. We know little about them. The bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found along the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few remaining show signs of stress.

Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to pinpoint why their numbers are dropping. Overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens local fishing industries, also affects dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are overfished in one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses large nets that float or are dragged quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on French and Cornish beaches, showing marks from these nets.

Pollution also affects dolphins. Waste and chemicals in the sea can accumulate in their bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk with high pesticide levels, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk.

Perhaps the most debated threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It's a great way to keep balance in your life, especially when everything around you feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but it's truly beneficial. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to. Exercise improves muscle tone and quickly changes your body shape. It increases muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. Exercise also targets specific areas like thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored, but here's something new: exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep patterns. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. By now, these points should convince you that exercise is good for you. If not, common sense should. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, or weight training. Remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injury, so start slowly. If unsure, consult your doctor about what's best for you. Good posture is crucial for improving body shape. A stiff or sagging body is unattractive and lacks energy, leading to minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling your head up. This helps lift your chest for better breathing and makes your body look slimmer. When standing, if your chest is balanced, you should see your ankles. Stretching improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain posture, and prevents muscle injuries. Doing it four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What motivates filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman to leave their home comforts for months? It's the pursuit of the perfect shot. Among the many creatures in East Africa's jungles and plains, two of the hardest to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has faced six months of almost nonstop rain, leading to unexpected challenges. Newman mentioned they had to buy an expensive tool so Amanda can pull their vehicle out of the mud when it gets stuck. Their partnership has produced some of TV's best wildlife films, like their acclaimed film on leopards. Even while this film was airing, they were back in the wild, this time following the elusive jackal. This is common in TV partnerships. Traveling filmmakers have been exploring the globe to capture exotic wildlife since TV began.

I spoke with Newman during one of his rare visits to a safari lodge. "We sometimes argue, but we resolve it quickly," he says about his colleague. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they view animals similarly. "When we're on the move, we set up our tents each night. But now, we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m., we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask." Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a concern," says Newman. It's a tough life, but being alone in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman recalls filming a lion family where a lioness would greet their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they spend four months on location for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start," says Newman, "because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create films rich in atmosphere that capture the true spirit of the place and animals, touching people's hearts. Evoking an emotional response is better than appealing only to their intellect."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her typical day includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. 'Don't you get strange looks?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she replied. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'

Kendra's life is now all about being at her best for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to reach peak fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 nations participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure and expectations from the home crowd. People expect us to start well.'

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they're exciting to play. They have a lot of talent.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But Kendra notes that the World Championships are tough. 'You have to push yourself to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance, and you must be ready.'

In her 15 years at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the final whistle, we're all friendlier.' Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, she believes in having a strong mental attitude and leading by example. 'I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team.'

'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, her focus is on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

Text: 'In hot water Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, studying chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When not teaching, she dives three kilometres into the Atlantic Ocean in a small steel vehicle to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'space is so limited that I can touch the two pilots. We can't stand or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.' 'If there's a problem and we need to surface quickly, we can hit a panic button. The outside drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that rises rapidly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey.' 'I didn't know how I would react the first time I entered the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and I got in with an instructor. He explained emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing my reaction to being in such a small space.' Rachel has now made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. 'We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. On the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. It's where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effect of a multi-national programme that would drill a 150-metre hole through a volcano.' When not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it to continue my research into the "black smokers". This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at one metre per second and at 350 degrees.' 'The only time I was frightened was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We stared at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!' 'Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body language, and how we speak, including our tone and volume.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher's only comment was, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look as if they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to come across in the best possible way." Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even given an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what had happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from words, 38% from voice, and 55% from facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job on the spot. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to turn him down. Consequently, he offered me a lower salary than I'd hoped for. I'm sure I could have got more had I managed to control my excitement."

Finally, consider what you say and how you say it. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests informing yourself about the company before an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and convince others of your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London but now runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a top local hotel. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but surprisingly, I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor was surprised when I said, 'I don't want to go back to where I've been.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work immediately for money. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left our friends, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner with even more hours, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that never happened. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss social interaction with colleagues, but I love being responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my destiny."

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a trial with a professional football club, but I chose athletics. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because of the excellent facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to decline. Dedication is crucial in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so late-night parties are out of the question. I miss sleeping in, but it's worth it. Without dedication, I wouldn't have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if there's prize money, I treat myself to a nice trip. The sacrifices pay off because winning the championship led to presenting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and celebrate wins in style. Some say we act childishly, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can't focus on the sport all the timeâ€”it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've only been recognized in public a few times. I wouldn't want to be a celebrity. I get many requests for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit overwhelming with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like the attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport. You have to be serious and professional. I'm focused on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children want everything they see, from sugary cereals to Disney videos and comics. She feels guilty if she gives in to their demands, but also feels bad for saying no all the time. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over Â£150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and health arguments about sugar don't compete well with appealing ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's important for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated that they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a major source of stress for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be critical of ads. As a result, they have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're unhealthy, even while buying treats for themselves. He acknowledges that it's natural for children to want nice things, but he still gets annoyed by their demands. His willingness to say yes often depends on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without a child's demands could attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large 18th-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the installation of the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost Â£250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, fitting for a five-star hotel. MacCann is confident it will pay off over time. 

For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible thanks to the guest-history feature, where staff can record various preferences. Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. A high-tech system allows guests to adjust the temperature within a small range, and the front desk can make larger adjustments between 14Â°C and 25Â°C.

Business travelers, who MacCann expects will make up 65% of the hotel's clientele, will appreciate the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. To keep up with fast-changing technology, the hotel has installed extra cables for future upgrades. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be easily updated, and DVD recorders can be upgraded as needed.

Despite all this technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms are designed to be both comfortable and welcoming. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

As with all luxury hotels, excellent food is a must. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his business to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular and successful restaurant without financial risk. With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

Text: 'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I need to be doing something challenging. When I'm learning something new, I feel a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, also energizes me. Dance is expressive and energizing. I think you feel drained if you're bored or feel life is pointless. Being effective in the world, even in small ways, gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all. I love being at work; it's not a chore. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel low, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep, so when I get it, I feel great. When I only get six hours of sleep, I feel a bit off. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to find the energy to do it! I do a yoga class once a week before work and try to do a workout at home. After exercise, my spirits rise a lot. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon, so it's probably good to eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthily for energy - I think it's natural enthusiasm and being positive. I can't stand negative attitudes. I'm quite naive - I think we should all enjoy life and seize the moment. Enjoyment comes first. You need to achieve things and set goals. I enjoy my work, and the last two years have been very exciting. In my job, there are many lively young people, and you can't help but be affected by that. I love rushing around for jobs and having a busy life. I'm very sociable. I enjoy taking photos, but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I rush to get them developed and can't wait to see them. I've also started writing lyrics for imaginary songs - it's just for fun and a good mental release when I'm traveling.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home with my family, and I think being positive about life helps. That's why I love working with kids; they give so much and have natural resilience. Energy is like a natural chemical, triggered by communicating with others - just try smiling at people and feel the thrill when they smile back. It's much better than feeling sorry for yourself. Although I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, I don't have an exercise plan. The most energetic I get is running around and playing with the kids.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'What I love most is making a garden out of wasteland. I did that once. The garden was solid concrete - I broke up all the concrete and added lots of soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. Another thing that gives me energy is knowing someone wants to read what I'm writing - I find it hard to write without an audience. I also like sneaking into a farmer's land or a wood. If I'm caught, I say "Oh, what a wonderful wood, I didn't know it was private," and so on. I like it because it's childlike.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'I believe you must have interest and respect for what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do wears you out. I used to be on various committees and resented the demands on my time. You only have so much energy, so focus it on what's most important to you.'

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight; this means leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is key in skating, more than in other sports. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should turn outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It's quite simple, isn't it? As you practice, you can gradually increase the length of your movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall, which reduces the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn basic figures, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you'll notice how relaxed and smooth they are. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson spoke with three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges they face.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**

Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "The work is tough right now. There's no time for TV, hanging out with friends, or doing much besides gym and school. I take training one day at a time. When I'm extremely tired, my coach might give me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you'll get stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**

"Annika showed great potential from a young age. Some parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People say we've sacrificed a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. She used to be shy, but now she's confident and has met people worldwide."

**C. Sarah Stokes**

Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me to events. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love the excitement. Even without my parents, I'd do it because I'm determined. I'm glad theyâ€™re happy when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal is to qualify for the British young riders team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

**D. Sarah's Mother**

"Sarah's passion for horses started at age 1. By 5, she was up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel across England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**

Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. I don't concentrate much during games; I just look around. I'm not worried about being arrogant. I don't talk about my success at school because I dislike embarrassment."

**F. Jane's Mother**

"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father suggested it, and she loved it immediately. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her talent. If she has this gift, she should reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, 'What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two metres tall at that age. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about a centimetre. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're evolving into a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the caveman era. We're now overcoming the effects of generations of poor diet, which is having a big impact. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by a few remaining hunter-gatherer tribes. One study found that they used 85 different wild plants in their diet. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas on the planet were taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This limited diet has negatively affected human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have relied on soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, turned out to be a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. Despite this, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gatherer land. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it comes with its own challenges. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't adapted. Standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly updating their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We can't grow forever. There must be a natural limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University of Chicago, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller, an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies retain heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even with proper nutrition. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even more. In other words, global warming could counteract human growth.'

**Studio Audiences: What's it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made?**

Cosmo Landesman explored this experience. Studio audiences are a common part of TV production, yet they remain a mystery to many. Watching them cheer on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people? Among live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least prestigious. Some in the TV industry even look down on them, treating them poorly, as one cameraman described, "like cattle."

I used to think studio audiences were just people eager for a brief moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life, professions, and income levels. TV shows aim to attract different types of people for different programs. Those of us who prefer watching TV at home might not understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and endure hours of waiting in an uncomfortable studio to watch something you can see at home?

One idea is that people hope to appear on TV for a moment. I doubted this until I met Angela, who said she came for the chance to be on TV. Another reason might be curiosity about what happens behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was simply, "a friend gave me a ticket."

Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it's like. You imagine sitting tightly packed with strangers, following signs to APPLAUD or LAUGH. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, "We always assume a show will be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed feeling part of live TV. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot." Personally, I missed seeing live actors because my view was blocked. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I prefer places where nature and human elements mix. When I travel, I like visiting charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. At eight, I went to school in England and would cycle to Lastingham village on Saturdays. Cycling was my escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the hilltops, valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt both familiar and different. I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a diary, which was my first step into travel writing, a field where I later became known.

**Sophia**  
There's a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by enthusiasts. I always travel first class as it's only slightly more expensive. The scenery isn't spectacular, just Romney Marsh with sheep and a canal. But I love when the train passes through back gardens. We get a glimpse of people in their daily lives, like making tea or doing chores. I see myself as a woman on a tiny train, peeking into others' homes. The ordinary landscape attracts me, just fields, sheep, and a distant sea. It makes me look closer for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful, remote coast. The beaches are rocky and hard to reach, so there are few crowds. Some brave surfers visit, but most people come to admire the sea's majesty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through valleys full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. Few people live or visit there. It's a hidden, remote area, and I love the sense of space. I found it by chance as a student and have visited every year since, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It saddens me that he grows up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon at twelve. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's my dream house, secluded and romantic. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys being around them. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited because she had found a pine snake. She asked if we could keep it, and I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank for temporary animal guests, and one night was enough to admire them and check our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting for help from their bedroom. I rushed in to find Domino, our cat, with Bianca, a white mouse, in his mouth. Bianca was a Mother's Day gift to me. Domino was running around the room, trying to escape with his catch, while the kids waved their arms to stop him. I joined the chaos and accidentally fell over. As I lay on the floor, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank.

The room was a mess of jumping kids, a barking dog, and the snake slithering around. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and returned to the bedroom. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I turned my attention to the snake. It was difficult to handle, but I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, trying to calm it down. Eventually, the snake relaxed, and I carefully lifted it. I took it to the garden, hoping it would choose to live in the shed. When I released its head, expecting it to attack, it instead wrapped around my shoulders like a shawl.

We stood there, my four children, the snake, and I, in the evening light. My eldest, DJ, explained why the snake stayed with me: "You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." We gently encouraged the snake to move on, and it slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed it up for all of us: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Drop me a line! In today's fast-paced world of phones, emails, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter offers a unique experience that other forms of communication cannot match. There's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it's from, and the enjoyment of reading it. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always insisted I write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Occasionally, my father would write, and it was always a joy to receive his long, funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday events involving my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but it's the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I often had relationships with people who had to work or study away, and we stayed in touch through letters. Instead of harming the relationships, letter writing seemed to improve them. I found I could often express myself more easily in writing than in speaking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to have a year's worth of news! It's even more exciting when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out on a wonderful friendship. Now, we have a regular correspondence. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local press even reported it on the front page. I am pleased that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I insist they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art**

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being gradually destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they might not survive for future generations. The mountain, once a site for prayer and worship, is covered with 4,000-year-old drawings carved into bare rock. These include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as the site becomes more popular, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He describes seeing tourists stepping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and the artwork's details. Some visitors even take parts of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to get a clearer picture," he said. "The drawings are polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them properly, they simply rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers describe how people arrive with long sticks with sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or even their names into the rocks. But experts disagree on the best way to preserve the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to turn the whole mountain into a 'no-go' area, allowing the public only on guided tours. Otherwise, he says, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research work will be reduced.

Clottes disagrees. "The measure proposed by Henry de Lumley is the most severe, and while it is the most effective, it is also certain to bring protests from people who live there," he said. "The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there."

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to avoid closing the site. "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal," he said. "Our department feels that the best solution is to let people look at the site, but because the area is very big, it is difficult to prevent visitors from damaging it. I would prefer that everyone was able to look at it, but the main problem is financial. We do not have the funds to employ the necessary number of guards. We may have to consider charging a fee. There seems to be no prospect of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also worked on researching the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reachâ€”tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehiclesâ€”the damage will increase rapidly. She thinks the only solution is to rope off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she said. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take steps, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children want everything they see, from sugary cereals to Disney videos and comics. She feels guilty if she gives in to their demands, but also feels bad for saying no all the time. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over Â£150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and health arguments about sugar don't compete well with appealing ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's important for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated that they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse can be stressful for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be critical of ads. As a result, they have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his children because they're unhealthy, even while buying treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent, as his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

Text: 'Climbing Walls Once, climbers only went to mountains. Now, challenging climbs can happen anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd watches closely. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events feature a climbing wall. This is possible due to new and fast-developing technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing angles. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, top climbers needed to stay fit. With cliffs unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This kept their fingers strong and helped avoid boredom. Soon, sports centers began building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges. Many early walls followed Don Robinson's example. He was a physical education teacher who, in the mid-1960s, built a climbing wall at Leeds University. Robinson's idea was to set natural rock in concrete blocks for walls. Many such walls were built in sports halls during the 1970s, but they had design issues. Walls were only vertical, unlike natural cliffs with overhangs and angled slabs. Once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the repetitive holds. In 1985, a Frenchman, Francois Savigny, created a material shaped like natural cliff features. These could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted variety. French manufacturers also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhangs without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. A system of interchangeable fixtures provided climbers with endless new holds.'

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. Acting is indeed a risky career because there are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, while others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it's a personal decision, and only you can take responsibility for your ambition. There are no easy paths - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after training, you will succeed. It's about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes big rewards. People often ask what talent is. I think it's natural skill plus imagination, with imagination being the hardest to judge. It also involves courage and belief in what you're doing. Why do people want to act? It's hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the key moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might shrug because they don't really know. They understand their skills and techniques but take nothing for granted, knowing their success depends on their current job. Disappointment is an actor's biggest enemy. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs. Suddenly, you get an audition, but you might not get the part, no matter how much you want it. So, actors don't talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of competing and possible rejection. Nobody likes rejection, and it's a possibility from the start. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it's up to you, because if you don't care enough, no one else will.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles currently available.

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from around the world, showcasing her love for exciting food and her understanding of what the average cook can achieve in a typical kitchen. Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course is the book that made her famous and has become a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to book for anyone asking, "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur, untrained chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His first TV series, Blanc Mange, is accompanied by a book of the same name. Raymond aims to make us better cooks by explaining how and why ingredients behave as they do. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 impressive recipes and serves as a practical guide, explaining why some dishes fail and introducing basic food chemistry. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows he's excellent at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. For over 100 years, this renowned cooking school has trained students to achieve excellence. To celebrate its centenary, the school has released the Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook, featuring 100 of its most esteemed recipes. While the recipes are classic, they remain fresh and have been adapted to reduce calories by moving away from rich, creamy sauces. The book starts with kitchen basics and continues with sections on Appetisers and Starters, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their secrets.

D. Fast food? Not necessarily bad! Nigel Slater, food editor of The Observer, challenges the idea that good food requires long hours in the kitchen with his book, The 30-Minute Cook. He believes fast food is perfect for when you come home tired and hungry, wanting something delicious quickly. Nigel has always thought you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza, and he has written two successful books to prove it. In this new book, you'll find over 200 enticing recipes from around the world, all ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel's lively and enjoyable writing style makes it clear that fast food can also be great food. If you're skeptical, try his recipesâ€”they're simply delicious.

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - Chris was already almost two metres tall at fourteen. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by another centimetre. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're creating a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the caveman era. We're now overcoming the effects of generations of poor diet, with significant results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by the few remaining hunter-gatherer tribes. One study found they used 85 different wild plants in their diet. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas have been taken over by farming, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has negatively affected human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have relied on soups, porridges, and breads, leaving us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, was actually a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it comes with its own challenges. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't adapted. Standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly updating their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We can't grow forever. There must be a natural limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies retain heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even with proper nutrition. As the planet continues to warm, we may shrink even more. In other words, human growth could be offset by global warming.'

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London but now runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. Supplying them helped my reputation grow, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but surprisingly, I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor helped me, and I was probably the first to say, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work for money, but our children were independent. We moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but our friendships have survived, and many visit us."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner with even more hours, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that never happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future."

Text: 'Onto a winner Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is very good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties with bushy beards, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the ancient game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and introduced it to his family. Soon, the family was playing the game every weekend and holiday, and as Dave says, 'having the best time ever'. Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico. But they didn't forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, made from old wooden food crates, and continued to play regularly. Visitors were often fascinated by the game, as it was unknown in southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed the old pichenotte board was cracked and worn, so he decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. 'People there started to watch,' says Dave, 'and say, "No way I'm playing that silly game." Then they'd sit down, and soon you couldn't get them up from the table!' When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched and found its roots were likely in India, with a similar game called 'carroms'. It was adapted into 'squails' in Britain, and British emigrants brought it to Canada a century ago. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. Pichenotte, played by two to four people, is a game of skill. Each player gets 12 pieces or 'pucks', which are 'flicked' across a wheel-like board using one hand. Flicking a puck into a small hole scores 20 points. Three rings around the hole score 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight tiny posts are obstacles. The game usually lasts two minutes. Seeing its popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity grew. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and started producing boards. Over 450 have been made so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick.
