Norm explains, 'They're very durable, as they have to withstand lots of use.' They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, but the brothers hope their garage will one day house a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they're happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will make them successful.'

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a piece of waste ground, flat and covered with brambles. For years, it was seen as useless land. However, with careful planning and hard work, one man, with the constant support of his wife, transformed it into the masterpiece you see today. Many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat site into the sculptured landscape you see now. Bulldozers and digging machines helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower-beds, and rockeries.

Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted in the Model Village. These plants had to be carefully chosen to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds in this exposed location. Most plants came from local garden centres, but some were brought from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims, who made over 100 models over nine years since the village first opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to withstand all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. You will notice that a constant scale is used, and even the smallest details are carefully crafted. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques.

The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses on modelling. All the model buildings show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on one specific place or structure. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small accident can lead to hours of repair work. Photography is allowed from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead. To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these to make the models operate.

At the end of your visit, we welcome any comments you might have. New models are always being planned, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models do not meet the village's standards, as we are constantly updating and replacing them. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish photos that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, these photos cause great harm to public figures when their private moments appear on the front page. However, very few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to handle such issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos and, since she was in a hotelâ€”a place where, according to the code of practice, 'there is a reasonable expectation of privacy'â€”she had a valid reason to complain, but she didn't take action. It is scandalous that the PCC did not investigate on its own. It should also look into the recent outrageous story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead on these and other shameful attacks? Initially, this seems like a good idea. It would likely result in many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it would no longer be financially viable to spend their days hiding to capture unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an inquiry? Should it approach the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still refused, should it proceed anyway? Additionally, celebrities and royalty might expect any story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. Above all, the role is too large. How could the PCC realistically monitor the entire British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there is the embarrassment factor. No matter how seriously someone's privacy has been invaded, would they want the further embarrassment of an investigation? Most people likely want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might exist that they have kept from the press, and they realize it could become public if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. One British comedian also suffered from the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor more recently, when he and his family were again photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would re-run the pictures with a new story about his 'fury', claiming it was just a bit of fun and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates receive advice about their first job. This article focuses on moving to a second job. We are not discussing those seeking a temporary job while looking for a permanent one, or those leaving an unsatisfactory job within the first few weeks. Instead, we are talking about those taking a significant step in their career, choosing a job that aligns with their ambitions after gaining some experience and skills. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Consider if you want to specialize in a specific area, move up to higher responsibilities, or transition into a broader field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next position. It should show evidence of serious career planning. Most importantly, it should challenge you, help you grow, and give you more responsibility. If you feel like traveling, now is the time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon. Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. It was a great first job because they were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no room for advancement. One day, she resigned, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Juliette now works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really expanded,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to develop me. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I have moved from mainly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also deal with various inquiries, from chairmen of large companies to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organize.'

**Confident People: What's Their Secret?**

Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but many say it's a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**

When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

**B. Michaela**

Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive, thinking that's what confidence was. I learned that to be confident, you need to believe in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lose confidence, so I talk to myself to overcome it.

**C. Lisa**

People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. In TV, looking confident is crucial. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous in important situations, and we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mother once told me, "Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves." I remember this advice. You gain confidence by facing fears. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed and felt less scared afterward.

**D. Barbara**

My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but it took years to build. By learning from mistakes, you become more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You need to like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's better to achieve small goals than aim too high and get nothing.

**E. Kim**

After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak in meetings. Eventually, I gained the confidence to share my opinions. When I started in politics, I was nervous about speaking in public. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing notes helped me feel more secure. Everyone feels a bit nervous speaking publicly. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, finders are keepers ... and I have many more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them under the shade of the coniferous trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, watching Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the center of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a row of competitors holding their kite lines waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites soared into the sky. Over 500 men and boys had registered for the five-day competition. Each entered four different designs judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them requires real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how it's done.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As it got dark, he invited me to return the next day to rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur into mountains covered with rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to ferry people across. Nearby, a sign pointed up a path into the forest: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' It would have been helpful to know that most of this path was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who managed a tented kitchen and bamboo huts. I decided to stay, ignoring the thought of insects under my mattress. The night was pitch black, filled with sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a stunning view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained heavily. Wind and lightning hit the treetops, and I got soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car being swept away and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kindness.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Whether you love it or hate it, everyone goes shopping. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ...

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**

I'm a shopping addictâ€”I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it keeps me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**

I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband the real amountâ€”I always say I spent less! The real price always sounds shocking.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**

I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring, and there's always something I'd rather be doing.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**

I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes gets it wrong!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**

I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and disorganized, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly!

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**

I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my girlfriends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**

I'm a careful shopperâ€”I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**

I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I have to check other shops for better dealsâ€”I take ages!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**

I'm an unwilling shopperâ€”maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I drag myself out, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than put in a lot of effort shopping!

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University offers degrees like any traditional university, but you can continue working while you study. It can also introduce you to a wide range of interests. If you have never studied before, you will experience the joy of expanding your knowledge. You will meet diverse people and make new friends. Your qualification might also lead to new career opportunities. Instead of attending regular lectures, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can choose to attend a class once a month at an Open University center. Like any university, there are exams to complete. If you want more information, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." Free quiz sheets are available at the Orange Street entrance desk. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz sheets are available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**

The Gallery has acquired a still life by Dutch 18th-century painter Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) of flowers and fruit is in light, bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778, as the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons. This picture was donated by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister Ida Nancy and is now on display in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently acquired works by three Spanish painters of this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain during these years - Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

A series of lectures accompanies the special exhibition every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery is pleased to announce an improved and expanded service in the Gallery restaurant. With new kitchens, the restaurant offers a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest pictures and showcase the range of the Gallery's collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning serious cooking. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay Â£280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

**Outdoor Centre Information**

- **Fees**: The fee covers a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Pay fees at the main office. The centre is open to the public and aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. Groups should inform the centre before visiting.

- **Windsurfing Course**: Beginner courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays, weather permitting. Learning to windsurf is exciting, especially the first time you sail across the water. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: Â£32.50 (includes all equipment).

- **Adventure Course**: Try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course introduces outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. No need to be very fit or have prior experience, just an interest in trying new things. Course fee: Â£22.50.

- **Play Park**: Suitable for children aged 2 to 10. It features sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, and a play castle. Next year, a new Play Palace and Play Ship will open.

- **Group Courses**: We offer day and weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit regularly. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, available for groups of 12 to 36 people.

- **Summer Adventure Holidays (Ages 8-14)**: Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is a top priority. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach. Children participate in age-appropriate activities. They must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**Stamp Collecting: A Hobby That Grows**

Millions of people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting, a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find an interest that can last a lifetime. Starting a collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends around the world.

Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways: we can send you a complete set on an envelope addressed to you, in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or as individual stamps for you to arrange in your own book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too. A two-year membership costs just Â£5, with a discount if a group joins together. This is great value for money. When you join, you receive a Starter Pack at no extra cost. It includes 100 stamps to start your collection and an attractive box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to add to your collection and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll receive the club magazine, full of competitions and quizzes, and opportunities to exchange stamps with members worldwide. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones.

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun of stamp collecting. To join, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the euro are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green the farmer would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies eventually started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Enter our story competition! You could win Â£1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other winners will receive Â£100 each. We are looking for talented writers who can create great stories. The judges, including novelist Mary Littlejohn, TV reporter Michael Brown, and Keep Writing's editor Susan Hitchins, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything, but here are some tips to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most writers followed it. Love, family, and friendship problems were common themes. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting for readers. Write about everyday things in a new and surprising way to keep readers engaged. Get your facts right If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure it's accurate. Don't write about things unless you're sure about them. Hold the reader's attention Start with an interesting beginning and end with a surprise. A poor ending can ruin a story. Develop your story carefully and think of an unusual ending. Think about the characters Make your characters come alive with well-chosen words. They should feel real to the reader. Your story must be original, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet. We cannot accept stories by fax or email, even if the deadline is near. Include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or recorded form, like on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. Your Â£5 entry fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The deadline is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within a month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had few opportunities to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. Although we have no copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to assist her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone associated with it was in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long and runs through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and goes to its headquarters at Wansford, near the main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are Â£10.00 for adults, Â£5.00 for children, and Â£25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great day out for the family. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station houses a unique collection of historic trains from across Europe. This includes famous engines like the elegant De Glen Compound from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. British engines like '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower' are also on display. You can see these trains all year, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of Â£2.00 for adults and Â£1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for Â£1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. Special low fares are available for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular venue for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programs can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they are found everywhere on Earth. They are the only flowering plants that can survive in the freezing conditions of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands support many kinds of animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area. Once they have eaten all the grass, new grass starts to grow, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, recently named Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards, has always had a passion for fashion. Since childhood, she has been drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never shared her dream of turning this hobby into a career with her parents, who own a supermarket, because she believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional career. So, she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She needed to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she admired, so she began making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her creations and asked her to make clothes for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis, and they sold out quickly. This success motivated her to leave her advertising job, take a Â£20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear label. Her parents were supportive of her decision, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than Â£500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal's business has grown significantly, and she feels very fortunate. "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this," she says.

**SUNNINGDALE HOTEL**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has offered excellent service to guests from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here. The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town centre, about 20 minutes by bus. Buses to various parts of the town stop outside the hotel, but avoid buses with the blue "Express" sign as they do not stop nearby. An underground station is less than 100 metres away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel offers a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests. Parking is available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay weekly in advance, with one week's notice required for departures. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9.30 am; lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm; and dinner from 5.30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires of any kind are allowed, and guests are asked to respect others' comfort. Please keep noise from tapes or CDs to a minimum, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests arriving by train are advised to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

Text: 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in cinema history. However, his life wasn't always easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and attended drama classes at the same time. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his thousands of fans worldwide.'

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a moving van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking around. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he brought her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, the cat's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the moving van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

Text: 'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm northern coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my journey. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, although the food is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship, would save time and money. A transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, everyone seemed excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners eager to board. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan waited four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge. I left the train at Alice Springs for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have delivered on everything the advertisements promise, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.'

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, and my first big winter climb. We took a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It's 600 meters up, probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls cut into the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard it's like walking on ice. Even though some of us were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety equipment, including lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothing. Although the weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, we still felt nervous when we started. Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon got steeper, and my legs felt heavy. Being the weakest in the group, I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they set off again. I promised myself that in the future, I would always train properly before a climb. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the route to the top of Ben Nevis. It's only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops away hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. However, we weren't so lucky, as a mist had come down. On Ben Nevis, getting back down to camp can be as challenging as going up. You need to read a map properly because a wrong turn could lead to slopes too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns doing that job. That first time, it was only when I was safe in the tent that I could say I really enjoyed the experience. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. However, this new school is one of the first in my country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched the whole process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, although it meant losing some lovely open space. The noise from the machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are much bigger than those in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings and other events. There's also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and large changing rooms that we can't wait to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you'll notice there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from usâ€”the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in. When we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is the tree on the school roof. The builders put it there because it's a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so big that you can see it from miles away! We took pictures to put on our website.

Even though we're using the school building now, some parts are still being added. For example, we're putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We're so happy with our new school, and our teachers say we'll learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever considered joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already purchase books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of Â£6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you save money on the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully selected from our book list by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll enjoy savings of 30% to 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, delivered straight to your door. You'll receive a free club magazine once a month, keeping you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

While you are a member, you only need to choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. Each month, our club magazine features a Club Choice book, either fiction or a reference title, offered at a special price. If you don't want this book, just indicate this on the form. We will send the book if we don't hear from you.

So, return your application form today, but hurry - offers like this don't come every day. To apply, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't luxurious, but it had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally emergedâ€”covered in mud but thrilled with what we had accomplished.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about Â£50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I felt lost: I'm 72 years old, far from home, and very worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. After I explained, he kindly gave me money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver my story, he let me keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they found my handbag and offered to bring it to me. I got my handbag back with everything still inside. I want to express how grateful I am to everyone who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the most fearsome creatures in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea creatures that they eat. Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For instance, unlike other fish, most sharks need to swim constantly to breathe and stay alive, so they rarely sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these fascinating animals.'

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only Â£1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, returning from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. Coach travel from Sydney to Melbourne via Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia. Nineteen nights' accommodation in quality hotels with full continental breakfast. Day trip to Ayers Rock, a full-day Barrier Reef boat trip, a visit to an Australian sheep station, and city sightseeing tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes. Hotel baggage handling. Experienced Globewise Tour Manager throughout the trip. PERTH Enjoy long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants, lush green parks, and the beautiful Swan River. City sightseeing tour included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs in the heart of Aboriginal country. Full sightseeing tour. Visit the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Travel to Yulara National Park. Visit the Olgas and Ayers Rock with its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Fly to the seaside town of Cairns and relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF Enjoy a full day's boat trip on the famous reef with the chance to see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY Experience the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city - includes a sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE Includes a city sightseeing tour - or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around and asked me questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and then they started speaking in English, so we managed to communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once to talk to her because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are very challenging, and I eat a lot to keep up my energy. This makes me confident that I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10Â°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. At the moment, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

Text: 'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, the Arctic was a popular summer destination to see the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice. By the late 1980s, people started to see the dark and cold winter as an opportunity. In the winter of 1990, French artist Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide. When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and new parts open each week until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outdoors using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather. In spring, the hotel melts as it gets warmer. Inside the hotel, the temperature stays between -5Â°C and -8Â°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Winter clothing like warm overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests are also advised to bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks, and to wear shoes larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items and the equipment you need when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for Â£45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for Â£30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The store's regular hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had announced it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. A police officer who was called to the store said: 'The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store quickly filled up, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could enter, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space inside. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. What surprised me was that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store. This completely blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained the situation. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

Text: 'Membership The Short Story Society supports writers in Britain today. Founded in 1899, it is now one of Britain's most active arts organizations. Society Magazines We publish several magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and offers new writers a chance to get published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene. You can read articles from recent issues by following the links on this website. National Short Story Competition We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Society members enter for free, while non-members pay a Â£5 entry fee. The competition runs from April to October each year. The top ten entries are published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner receives a publishing contract for their own collection of short stories. Education For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, inspiring children and teachers with new ideas and building their confidence in writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers. The Writers' Cafe The Writers' Cafe is the Society's social hub. It is relaxed and stylish, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in central London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events. Becoming a Member We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.'

Text: 'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on a single breath. In 2003, Tanya Streeter made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 metres into the ocean and return to the surface without assistance. She had gone deeper the previous year but used a balloon to help her ascend. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the only woman in any sport to break a man's world record. A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. Despite reports of serious accidents involving other divers, some people argue that free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya disagrees, emphasizing that safety and training are crucial. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine remains consistent. She spends two-thirds of her time on land-based training at the gym, with the rest split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, preferring fast walking to build fitness. When she starts practice dives, she usually travels away from home, aiming for fourteen dives over four weeks, with rest days in between to avoid fatigue. When not preparing for an event, Tanya often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects or films. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she spent her childhood swimming and exploring rock pools to observe sea life. Tanya says her life today is like living her childhood dreams. Known in some countries, she believes people listen to her on environmental issues. Looking ahead, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. Since she started free-diving at twenty-five, she emphasizes that she doesn't plan to retire from the sport anytime soon.'

Text: 'CARTOON FILMS Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the late 1970s, the cinema industry thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors had some original ideas. They showed it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a success. The Black Cauldron, for example, failed because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.'

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role 'I never expected to spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted at school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before university. While in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to turn the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the part. She was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the role. Filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. Once back at university, I woke up at 6.00am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I'm not from an acting family, though my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed it all, because I had a full social life too. When filming finished, I hardly knew what to do. I've since appeared in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over, I'm off to Greece for the summer with friends.''

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is an international company growing quickly worldwide. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on running a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. This book is not a typical business guide, nor is it just about my life. The key message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares these ideas with the world. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do too.'

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER VOYAGES JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience along the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and WC. The ship is air-conditioned and features a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library. Itinerary Day 1 Depart in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Upon arrival, your guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night. Day 2 Enjoy a morning of sightseeing in Oporto, then return to the ship and depart for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the river journey takes four hours. Day 3 Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, known for port wine production. At dinner, you can taste the local food and drink. Day 4 After breakfast, travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, has an excellent collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua. Day 5 Here, the Douro becomes very narrow. Depending on the river's depth, you may continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return journey to Tua is by coach, offering much to see along the way. Day 6 In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the most stunning views in the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take the Douro River Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting. Day 7 Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch, then set off down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on board the Lady Ivy May. Day 8 Arrive in Oporto with plenty of time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before catching your flight back to London Heathrow.'

Text: 'HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweetener because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. But honey is not just food - it can be used for sore throats and is found in many skin and hair-care products.'

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had become one of England's largest towns. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is relatively small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was England's second-largest city. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Although there are fewer churches and pubs now, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich in 1964. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' with green and yellow colors, though the origin of the name is unclear.

A modern shopping center, 'The Castle Mall,' is one of the city's attractions. For over two years, residents lived with a large hole in the city center as builders removed nearly a million tons of earth to create a park on the Mall's roof, featuring water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are thriving, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the old with the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a desert city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about a dozen hot-air balloons launching from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at its current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The pilots stay in radio contact and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in various sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Alternatively, you can take a cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates ideal conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival entrance. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you use film, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night photos.

Text: 'The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist spots. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a large waterfall. Another zone recreates the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.'

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality, for Â£6.99, quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less well-known authors seem to focus mainly on food. A word of caution about Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes! The collection also features fine work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, with a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an exceptional collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will include.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, prefers to take students at three and four, but she often makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson a week with her. Parents also need to attend the classes. It is important that the parents show interest in the lessons. From the earliest lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading of music. Margaret says that her method is not meant to produce great violinists, and she always suggests that students who perform particularly well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Text: 'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' follows their previous album 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now on bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it's clear the band is moving away from slow songs. The second track is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks are in the band's usual slow style. These two tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which led to the band canceling their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets need not worry as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create perfect music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the upbeat ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt they put their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as strong. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

San Francisco San Francisco is located on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from land, not from the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the former prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and interesting account of everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events of the time, such as disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his faults - he often slept during church or admired the pretty girls. He describes his home life, like a quarrel with his wife and how they made up, and his worry about her illness. Besides books, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not designed for comfort or style. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. Today, we still use leather, but materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are produced by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to make large quantities of cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to pause my running career. I wanted to help more women discover the sport, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to boost their confidence to start running. So, I started a women's running club in my area because I was frustrated with many race organisers. They often complain about the lack of women in the sport but use it as an excuse not to provide separate changing facilities. I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined. They were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and staying fit. I wanted to support women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress almost as much as they have.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built, including one called Iditarod, meaning 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During summer, supplies could reach these towns by boat, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, blocking access. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This trail was named the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to cross Alaska, stopping at 'roadhouses' for rest and food. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams. However, in 1925, dogs were needed again when diphtheria struck Nome. The cure was in Anchorage, far across Alaska. Airplanes were new and untested in such cold, and the only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail, and took twenty teams just six days. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers, relying on his dog Togo to guide him through the snow. The final part was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, an experienced dog team driver. His lead dog, Balto, refused to move at one point, saving the team from icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race is held annually from Anchorage to Nome, following the 1925 route. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of JukkasjÃ¤rvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40Â°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. At this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so placing hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are kept at around -4Â°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing is also available. The hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in the summer. Building it requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Text: 'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one minded that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who had supported other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He quickly noticed she was very fast. 'He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was really hard work and my legs hurt a lot.' But Jose visited her parents and convinced them that she could succeed and help lift them out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had refused before because she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She says, 'They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.'

Text: 'The Skywalk The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Visitors come to the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is spectacular, and the Skywalk makes it even more impressive. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, allowing you to see the canyon's stunning rocks. Up to 120 people can stand on it at once. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands have visited it. Visitors must wear special shoe covers to prevent scratching the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like floating high in the air, like a bird.'

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest but are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as impressive. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. You start in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. With the ocean at its feet and mountains at its head, Vancouver offers residents the chance to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from downtown.
