In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver daily on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey remains a great adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you pass through some of the most stunning scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago, when the rulers of China created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. This no longer happens, as zoos now aim to show animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters say zoos allow us to learn about the natural world and see wild animals up close, which wouldn't be possible otherwise. On the other hand, critics argue that it is wrong to keep animals in cages and that poorly managed zoos can have dirty conditions and provide unsuitable food for the animals.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was impressive, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even created new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets acceptedâ€”only about half do. However, anyone eager to play attends jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning its language. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the countryâ€”Iâ€™ve been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for serious music students like me. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old at the same timeâ€”you can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime between November and March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens don't rely on rain. Instead, they depend on a network of underground channels, built in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. These dry places that get water this way are called oases. Further south from Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, 13, is the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in a circus. They both found work with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and return home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Text: 'Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major national and local newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. The stories and articles accepted by these media can also be found on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers across the country where young people can meet other members and participate in projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide. Since our agency began in 1994, originally named 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was impressed by the opportunities the young journalists had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I started visiting the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and remained a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I imagined. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, reviewing articles before they are published.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over who train new members in basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff who accompany them. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training is in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free and there is no test to join.'

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, Antarctica Sightseeing Flights offers tours in a full-size passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Questions**

Here are answers to common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. Around four hours into the journey, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have lived on research stations in Antarctica give talks on the environment and history, and answer questions. A camera near the pilot, connected to the onboard video system, provides a pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, passengers switch to the seat on their second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to share the sightseeing opportunities. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over points of interest so that everyone can see the sights well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different approved flight plans. Our captain checks the satellite cloud images on the morning of the flight and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them in detail. We do not land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, definitely! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun onboard photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs Every Saturday, a group of children aged ten to fifteen learn serious cooking skills. These weekly lessons are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay Â£280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, a ten-year-old class member, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too keen at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. The car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, whenever you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it. Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, triple on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law, but instead, he went to art school. There, he found traditional drawing classes challenging, but he continued painting. In his late twenties, he received a grant from the Italian government to study art, which sparked his interest in early Italian artists. This influence is visible in some of his work. He admired the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. To achieve this, he painted colors thinly, layering them from light to dark, but he admits he's never sure of the outcome. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting, as he believes that if he did, he might lose interest and not complete the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are finished. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their pictures while he's working. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he has not felt connected to the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. Ben argued, 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our home with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. I must admit that, although their music sounds a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is unique because it offers students valuable experiences outside the classroom, along with their regular studies. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the mornings and spend the afternoons doing useful activities like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body, with students from various social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are PS20,000 for two years, many students receive grants. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can attend only because they get government support.

"I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education using methods that truly work.

Text: 'Being an Older Student At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. Besides attending lectures regularly, I have had to learn to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, even though I was earning a decent salary, I was bored with a job that didn't challenge my mind. I felt trapped in the job and became more and more unhappy. I envied the students at the local university, who seemed happy, carefree, and hopeful, and I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am grateful for this chance to study because I know a qualification is necessary for a fulfilling job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out partying. There are also typical student benefits like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I often wonder what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage has been a wise decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic and built his first car in 1893. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong yet light steel, he created affordable cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model T, priced at $825, and soon he was selling 100 cars a day. By 1927, the company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs Â£150. If you prefer to start in June, we have another 10-week course for Â£200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. 'You have to carry everything on your back,' she said, 'so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and eventually, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I'm usually a clean person, but there's no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only bring enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about the trip, and people often invite her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science programme on television. Rebecca is well known today and has more money, but she still lives in the small flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains.'

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was great; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some wonderful presents. I'll tell you more about it when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn's cold weather arrived, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to come back. They didn't arrive, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her Â£500 for her birthday. While most of her friends chose to go to college, Esther used the money from her aunt to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for Â£1 a jar to her friends and quickly doubled the Â£500. Initially, her parents were not happy with Esther spending her time making jam; they wanted her to study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She then started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked. After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She produced various foods and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire employees.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to join me at the cinema after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film begins at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm really sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline'

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they keep cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each one produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to prevent them from getting too warm. 

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people weren't interested in buying sweaters. So, she started making socks instead. The socks became popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This marked the beginning of Jenny's business.

Initially, Jenny made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are produced by machines. They come in six colors, five sizes for all ages, and are designed for walkers, sports enthusiasts, and skiers. Jenny's busiest time is Christmas, as Corryvale socks are a popular gift. Her office walls are covered with letters from satisfied customers worldwide.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived in Brighton three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school here. The students are from many different countries, and I've made many new friends. We have classes for five hours each day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me when I make mistakes. I plan to visit London next weekend because I'm returning to my country on Monday. Can I meet you there? Please write back soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by over 30% compared to last year. He mentioned that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave without closing a door or window. He added that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually home then. However, he noted that winter afternoons are ideal for burglars because it is dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Many houses are empty at this time since people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over other houses on the street when people are away and to call the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to make your house secure,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This advice is free of charge.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I want to thank you for letting me stay at your lovely home for two nights. It was great to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They turned out well, don't you think? I hope you like them. I really enjoy using my new camera. Next week, I'm visiting my sister in New York. I'll take many photos there, too. It's been a long time since I last saw her.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before farming began, people gathered plants and fruit from forests to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started to grow their own food. These were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, and their villages gradually expanded. Some villagers could focus on other tasks, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was challenging during bad weather, leading to food shortages. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it is transported thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she joined Saudi Arabian Airlines and later became an air hostess with British Airways. Four years after that, she got her current job as a manager. Here is what she shared about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I train air hostesses and assist them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My usual working hours are from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight schedules on my computer and then talk to some of the air hostesses. Occasionally, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are performing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I enjoy office work too. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, It's nice to be back in my home country, but I often think about the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I was sad when I left England because my stay was too short. I want to return to England, but next time I plan to stay in a different city. I've started taking English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still searching for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag with my name written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am pleased to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J. Wilson'

Text: 'People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various jobs. For instance, the weather greatly affects farmers. In the past, farmers spent a lot of time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather updates on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in traditional weather sayings. For example, they say that if there is a red sky in the evening, the next day will be sunny. Some also believe that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.'

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small Canadian town. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they've spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who had trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing information than by reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to create the game, and now it's ready to use. It's a speaking and picture game. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there's a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be available worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard to sleep because my mind is full of music. Sport is important too. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports centre. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's healthy. I aim for eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that. It's important not to work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's beneficial to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since my doctor advised me to eat better. Now, I eat lots of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still enjoy burgers occasionally!'

Text: 'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, surpassing the USA. Watching films is the most popular leisure activity in India, with ten million people going to the cinema daily. Bollywood films often feature romantic love stories, with singing and dancing as key elements. These films are also popular outside India, earning Bollywood over $500 million last year from international sales. Indian actors make more films annually than their Hollywood counterparts, but they earn less money. As a result, most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to produce, whereas a Hollywood film typically costs at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work intensely for a few years. However, Amitabh Bachchan, considered by some as India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in over 140 films during a career spanning nearly 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived there with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the U.S. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced life in two countries. I like Britain and want to return, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so it won't be for another four years. I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio programme about the English language and to discuss the book I've just written. Most writers don't enjoy this; they don't like travelling around the country to promote their book. I don't mind it. I enjoy visiting new places and meeting many people. It's very different from my life in the U.S. when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.'

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes arrived in England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer is a more recent arrival. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular trimming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and they are also employed by the police due to their intelligence. A Schnauzer is a good family dog. It is friendly and very good with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two large towns. 'It was very challenging because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best experience she has ever had. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite class today was Maths, and I was pleased because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time and really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he often shouts. I have to go now because I need to do my homework. Hester'

Text: 'New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, working in a small hospital. One day, a baby becomes very ill, and Maha has to drive all night to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey and ...

Hard Work  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They spend long hours making tables and chairs, but they have little money. Then one day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop ...

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who invites her to the USA to become a film star ... What will Tina do?'

Text: 'The history of horse racing Horse racing has been an important sport since ancient times. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in Greek and Roman times. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses were brought to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses. However, at the start of the 18th century, races became shorter and included several horses competing together. Today, horse racing is watched by more people than any other sport in the USA, except for baseball. It is also very popular in other parts of the world.'

Text: Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job. He travels worldwide to make TV programmes. "People welcome me everywhere, and when I return home, I remember all the wonderful experiences from each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but he still wants to travel to South America and return to Australia someday. On each trip, Nick travels with a team that brings cameras and other filming equipment. He doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always includes some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with his travels for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she enjoys hearing his travel stories. However, there can be challenges. Once, while in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick learned that Helen was ill in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better," he recalls.

Parrots You might have seen these beautiful birds with their vibrant colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots are native to countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They typically live in large groups, and because they enjoy eating fruit, they can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many different species of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are intelligent birds and can be easily taught to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a charming village about fifty kilometres west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he's already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He's only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and dine in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he's sure he's done the right thing.'

Text: In a park in a small town in central England, John Pickering takes care of the grass and flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. John, a thirty-five-year-old gardener, is currently the top singer in Japan. He visited Japan a few months ago to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the station, asking to hear the songs again. John, who goes by the name Jon Otis when singing in Japan, plans to continue working in the park in England. He is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Text: 'Memo To: All staff Subject: Holidays From: D Brown Date: 22.2.02 I am organizing the holidays for next year. Please let me know your preferred holiday dates. If possible, provide two options. Please respond by the end of the month. Thank you. D Brown Memo To: D Brown Subject: Holidays From: J Green Date: 23.2.02 May I take a two-week holiday in July? I prefer the first two weeks, but if that's not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Additionally, can I have three extra days off in the first week of December? John'

Text: 'Line Dancing Thousands of people in Britain have taken up a new hobbyâ€”line dancing. In nearly every town, you can find clubs and classes for this activity. "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you have two feet and can walk, then you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!" When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the others live in Asian forests. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos at birth and stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, policemen are everywhere, but in 1700, London had none. A few old men used to guard the streets at night, and they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London began to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people stayed home as much as possible. In 1750, Henry Fielding started paying a group to stop thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown very large and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was created with 3000 officers. Most worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are well paid, and for the few who still ride horses, the pay is even better.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers, a small shop, and bicycle rentals. The trip costs Â£25. It gets very cold at night, so please bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to join, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it's often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be hard, so consider booking your hotel now!'

Text: 'ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and thousands of Canadian fishermen visit each weekend. They build small wooden huts on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these huts, they fish for the fish swimming under the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. 'You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy,' he says. 'First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then, you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!''

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm not having a great week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without asking me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can. Greg '

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's Museum A very popular tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Visitors can see wax figures of famous people there. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and opened a museum for them in Paris. Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802 she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures are still on display today.'

Text: 'BICYCLES Bicycles are an affordable and eco-friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, so only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we see today. As bicycles became more affordable, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles to commute to work and for leisure. Nowadays, cars are used more than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still prefer cycling to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers and parking is difficult to find!'

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large square with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of large white cards. Each elephant received a paintbrush and began painting on its card. Occasionally, the keepers gave them new brushes with fresh paint and took the old ones away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants drew pictures. I was amazed! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats. They vary in size and have different appearances and behaviors. Tigers are the largest of the big cats. They can be up to 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and often cool off in pools when it's hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups called prides. Several lions may work together to hunt for food for the pride. They typically live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. All big cats need excellent eyesight to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I am sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I have to return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents are preparing a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sorry to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you again. Best wishes, Soraya'

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please let me know when you are free and where I can meet you. Hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I'd love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There's a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm happy because I got a new job in the city centre last month. I work in a Tourist Information Office, and it's very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Although ostriches have wings like all birds, they cannot fly. Instead, they use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches are very fast runners, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the size of chickens and take around 3 years to mature into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has since won many competitions. We interviewed her last week at a snowboarding event in Switzerland and asked why she took up the sport. She said, "I've always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It's quick to learn, and you can become skilled in just a few months." 

When asked about her practice routine, she explained, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains daily from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding outside of competitions, is my favorite thing."

We also asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She advised, "You can learn quickly, but lessons are necessary. It's also crucial to have the right clothing to stay dry, as beginners spend a lot of time falling!"

Text: '23 Oak Avenue Manchester Dear Sir or Madam, I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15th to 17th. I prefer a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please provide a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel. Does the hotel have a car park? I expect to arrive around 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your assistance. Yours faithfully, Mark Jones'

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. People of all ages have climbed it, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different routes to reach the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to complete and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers manage to reach the top. This is often due to sudden weather changes. At the start, it can be hot and wet, but at the summit, climbers encounter ice and snow, with temperatures possibly dropping below 20 degrees. Therefore, climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothing.

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move at more than 10 kilometers per hour in the water. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were few otters in Great Britain because the rivers were polluted, and many fish and insects died, leaving otters with little to eat. Today, the rivers are clean again, providing plenty of food for them.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, I'm excited to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I'm fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family and will send more next time. I hope to hear from you soon. Tom'

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are an excellent teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying medicine. I will stay with him for two weeks before returning home to Greece. I really like London. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. The weather was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I will visit your country next month with two friends. We are unsure about where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would prefer to stay in the city center. Can you assist us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the city center are costly, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to store beautiful things. Many people collaborate on a building project. The architect designs the building's appearance and creates drawings to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, the workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with an elegant roof. However, the building is beautiful from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month and is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I've grown so much that all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is known as the Cerne Giant because it is near the village of Cerne. The exact age of the Cerne Giant is unknown, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 metersâ€”and possibly the 5,000 metersâ€”at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always maintained a cheerful attitude, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of the year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, was also a runner in his youth, but he had to stop competing due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail, although it's challenging for him when she overtakes him. Gail trains diligently, doing a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes Sundays off. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually about cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Text: 'Young Piano Players Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. By ten, he wanted to write music and soon composed his first song. Oleg Gagarin Oleg was the youngest of five children. At four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning piano prizes. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia. Josef Heptmann Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano at three. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now but hopes to write his own music someday.'

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office and in the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' says Bill. His ten grandchildren, who don't live nearby, also read his stories and give their opinions. This feedback helps Bill understand what young children enjoy reading. Bill writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, The Sheepdog, which is about a farmer and his helpful dog. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are so clever, they learn very quickly.' Last year, The Sheepdog was made into a film using real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine and I love the film,' he says.

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it showed a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards began to feature images of current events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they became extinct about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied greatly in appearance. There were over 5000 different species. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and was a plant-eater. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as large, but it was more powerful. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast due to its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they find food using their noses. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in tropical areas around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water but can move quickly both in water and on land. Crocodiles are often seen in large groups. They eat anything they catch, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are over ten different types of crocodiles, all with very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth but grow new ones quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. Crocodiles can live for many years; the oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes changed significantly. In the 1950s, they became much faster due to jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, making the trip from London to New York only four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet in bad weather. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre by the River Thames to watch William Shakespeare's plays. All the actors were men at that time. Visitors ate, talked to friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will visit the Great Barrier Reef. The water there is warm, and I love swimming. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home! See you at the end of September. Sue'
